**Summary:** Srila Prabhupada reads and translates verses from the Bhagavad Gita describing Arjuna's reluctance to fight and his internal conflict on the battlefield.

OM NAMO BHAGAVATE VASUDEVAYA. Reading from Srimad Bhagavad Gita, Chapter 1, Entitled, Observing the Army on the Battlefield of Kuruksetra, Verse No. 45: YADIMAM APRATITARAM ASASTRAM SASTRA PANAYAH DATARASTRA RANIHANYOS TANME SHEMATARAM BHAVET. Translation and Purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swamishila Prabhupada: I would consider it better for the sons of Dhritarashtra to kill me unarmed and unresisting rather than fight with them. Purport by His Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swamishila Prabhupada: It is a custom according to kṣatriya fighting principles that an unarmed and unwilling foe should not be attacked. Arjuna, however, in such an enigmatic position, decided he would not fight if he were attacked. He did not consider how much the other party was bent upon fighting. All these symptoms are due to soft-heartedness resulting from his being a great devotee of the Lord. Verse No. 46 I will read myself. Sanjaya uvacha evam uttvarjunasankhe rathopastupa visat visrajya sasaramchapam sotra samvitnam anasah. Translation: Sanjaya said, Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, tossed aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief. Perfect. While observing the situation of his enemy, Arjuna stood up on the chariot, but he was so afflicted, he pleaded with lamentation that he sat down again, setting aside his bow and arrows. Such a trained and soft-hearted person in the devotional service of the Lord is fit to receive self-knowledge. I would consider it better for the sons of Dhritarashtra to kill me unarmed and unresisting rather than fight with them. Sanjaya said, Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief.

yadimam apratikaram asastram sastra-pāṇaya. It is the custom between the kṣatriyas, that in the fighting, if the other party hasn't got a weapon to fight, this party will supply him a weapon. Note that the other party without a weapon, and this party will take the opportunity to kill him. This is not the rules and regulation of fighting. There are many rules and regulations of the fighting. Not that because he's my enemy, I shall kill him anyway. No. There are rules and regulations. If the enemy has broken his chariot, he's fallen down on the ground, he's been killed. The other party also will immediately get down from the chariot. Suppose he is fleeing, then if one is on foot and another on the chariot, so he will be in a superior position. Therefore the opposite party must also get down from the chariot and walk with him. That means the defeated enemy should be given all opportunities. So he may not think that unnecessarily, in a weak position, he has been killed. No. So Arjuna says… Arjuna, of course, did later on. When he killed Karna, Karna was without a weapon, and he fell down from the chariot. Karna, after falling down from the chariot, and he was trying to raise the wheel of the chariot from the mud. So Kṛṣṇa asked Arjuna that this is the opportunity to kill him. You kill him immediately. So at that time he had no weapons, and he was trying to kill Karna, and he fell down from the chariot. And in that position he was killed by Arjuna, by the order of Kṛṣṇa. This is violating the laws. So you can violate the laws on the order of Kṛṣṇa. You cannot do this. This is surrender. When Kṛṣṇa says that you do this, although it is wrong, you have to surrender. You cannot do that.

But even though they have all these counteracting machines or counteracting agents, still without your sanction these counteracting machine or agent will not be fruitful. Similarly Arjuna is being protected by Kṛṣṇa. So even though Arjuna is not well equipped of prati-kāra, still he will be saved. Because Kṛṣṇa is there. tāvat vibhūtaṁ vṛtāṁ tad-peksitāṇā And even one is well equipped and if Kṛṣṇa does not like to save him, he will not be saved. Always mind this. rāke kṛṣṇa māreke māre kṛṣṇa rākeke This is ordinary. If Kṛṣṇa wants to kill you, nobody can save you. And if Kṛṣṇa wants to save you, nobody can kill you.

#### compassion, ignorance, self-realization, duty
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/3AxaWNAZbWU?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Compassion for the eternal soul is real self-realization."
**Summary:** Srila Prabhupada explains the first verse of the second chapter of Bhagavad-gita, focusing on Arjuna's compassion and Krishna's role in dispelling ignorance.

Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya. In Shri Ramasuramad Bhagavate Gita, Chapter 2, Contained Bhagavate Gita, Summarized, Verse 1: Sanjayo Vacha Tam Tathakrupaya Vishtam Ashrupurna Kulekshanam Vishidantam Hidam Vakyam Vacha Madhusudana. Translation in Perpetual Bhai's Divangresh Translation: Sanjayo said, seeing Arjuna full of compassion and very sorrowful, his eyes brimming with tears, Madhusudana, Krishna, spoke the following words. Perpetual compassion, lamentation, and tears are all signs of ignorance of the real self. Compassion for the eternal soul is real self-realization. The word Madhusudana is significant in this verse. Lord Krishna killed the demon Madhu, and now Arjuna wanted Krishna to kill the demon of misunderstanding that had overtaken him in the discharge of his duty. No one knows where compassion should be applied. Compassion for the dress of a drowning man is senseless. A man fallen in the ocean of nescience cannot be saved simply by rescuing his outward dress, the gross material body. One who does not know this and laments for the outward dress is called a Shudra, or one who laments unnecessarily. Arjuna was a Kshatriya, and this conduct was not expected from him. Lord Krishna, however, can dissipate the lamentation of the ignorant man, and for this purpose the Bhagavad Gita was sung by him. This chapter instructs us in self-realization by an analytical study of the material body and the spirit soul. As explained by the supreme authority, Lord Shri Krishna, this realization is made possible by working with the fruity being situated in the fixed conception of the real self.

#### transcendental form, material conception, Absolute Truth
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/3AxaWNAZbWU?t=553
**Verse References:** SB 1.2.6
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Nārāyaṇa is not anything of this material world."
**Summary:** Srila Prabhupada explains that Krishna, Vishnu, and Narayana are beyond the material world and that the term 'nirakara' means that God's form is not material.

And in the Śrīmad-Bhāgavatam also it is said, sabhi-puṁśāṁ paro dharmaḥ. Paro means transcendental. Beyond this material conception, Kṛṣṇa or the Absolute, Nārāyaṇa, that is paro, Nārāyaṇa-paro of bhakti-āyam. Nārāyaṇa is not anything of this material world. Nārāyaṇa, Kṛṣṇa, Viṣṇu, the Absolute Personality of Godhead, He is not anything of this material world. When we use this word nirākā, that means He is not anything of this material world. But He has got His form, that is transcendental form, sac-cid-ānanda-vigrahaḥ. Nirākār means He has no such form as we have got this material form. This material form is neither of the three transcendental bliss, sac-cid-ānanda-vigrahaḥ, this is asat, acit, and nirānanda-vigrahaḥ. This body, this material body is asat, acit, and nirānanda-vigrahaḥ. Therefore when in the Vedic literature on an authorized statement we find nirākār, that means His form does not belong to this asat, acit, or nirānanda-vigrahaḥ.

#### renunciation, Vrindavan, Navadvipa Dham, parampara
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/6zqIuMP19VM?t=56
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "After the demise of his wife Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj left the country, left his business and went to Vrindavan."
**Summary:** Srila Prabhupada narrates the early life and renunciation of Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj, including his time in Vrindavan and Navadvipa Dham.

Today is the most auspicious disappearance day anniversary of one of the previous acharyas in our Sampradaya, His Divine Grace Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj. So, a brief biography of Srila Gaur Kishodas, let us hear, and by his blessings, we will be able to advance in our Krishna consciousness by trying to follow some of the instructions that he has very nicely given us. Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj appeared sometime in the 1830s in the village of Vagyana in East Bengal, or Vagyana in East Bengal, which is what is now known as Bangladesh. During his boyhood, his mother and father arranged a marriage for him, and he remained in household affairs for more than 20 years. While a householder, he worked as a broker in the grain business, but even at that time, he exhibited his spirituality. After the demise of his wife, Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj left the country, left his business, and went to Vrindavan. There he approached Srila Bhagavad Das Babaji, one of the foremost disciples of Srila Jagannath Das Babaji Maharaj, and accepted from Bhagavad Das Babaji Maharaj the traditional Paramahamsa Vaishnava Babaji dress. After this, he became completely renounced and would stay under trees in various parts of the forest of the 168 mile Vraja Mandala or Vrindavan area. He continuously acted thus for a period of approximately 30 years. During this time, he would sometimes travel to the holy places of pilgrimage in northern and western India. Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj became very famous among the great devotees of Vrindavan and was awarded the appropriate title of Bhajananandi. Bhajananandi means one who is dedicated to remain in one place and chant the holy name of the Supreme Lord and completely absorb themselves in the chanting and hearing of the holy name of the Supreme Lord, but we should not try to imitate such great devotees; rather, we should accept the instructions of our spiritual master and try to follow those instructions in our practical life while hearing the great qualities of our spiritual master and the previous Acharyas and their great deeds of devotion and service dedicated entirely for the pleasure of the Supreme Lord. Even though he received such honor, he never endeavored for even a small bit of material sense gratification and totally disapproved of the secret material desires of pseudo-renunciants and so many people who try to imitate great devotees, and prematurely they try to renounce this world, but it is not very easy to maintain the standard of renunciation exhibited by such paramahamsas as Sri Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj. He would perform his pure unalloyed devotional pastimes alone in a profound devotional mood. In the year 1897, during the month of Falgunna, when he was in his sixties, Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj proceeded to Navadvipa Dham from Vrindavan Dham, and under the instruction, he did this under the instruction of Srila Jagannath Das Babaji Maharaj. From this time until his disappearance, Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj remained in Navadvipa Dham and in different villages

#### renunciation, simplicity, detachment
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/6zqIuMP19VM?t=353
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "These are considered totally impure but a renunciant has nothing to do with purity and impurity of this world."
**Summary:** This segment describes Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj's extreme renunciation and detachment from material possessions, highlighting his acceptance of things considered impure by others.

he was visiting the various places of pastimes of Lord Gauranga, and he was realizing the non-difference between Navadvipa Dham and Vrindavan Dham. He begged by gathering dry foodstuff from the householders of the holy Dham. He would sometimes offer these foodstuffs to the Supreme Personality of Godhead by simply holding them in his hand. He was totally renounced, so he didn't have any elaborate arrangements for offering or cooking or anything like that. In order to cook, he would collect dry wood from the footpath, and he would wash earthen pots discarded by the villagers along the roadside near the Ganges River on the occasion of eclipses. These are considered totally impure, but a renunciant has nothing to do with purity and impurity of this world. Just he would take something of no value to others, and somehow with those bare minimum things, he would maintain himself. This would actually ensure that such great devotees are never entangled in any material endeavors. They save time, maximum amount of time, for their spiritual activities exclusively. In order to clothe himself, he would go to the shore of the Ganges and collect and wash discarded cloth that had been used to cover dead bodies at the burning heart. This was his level of renunciation. Thus, he always remained independent of the support of others simply by utilizing items of no value to others.

His guru is Srila Gaur Kishodas Babaji Maharaj, and His shiksha guru is Srila Bhaktivinoda Thakur. This is the parampara in which Srila Prabhupada, the founder Acharya of ISKCON, is coming. This is what is taught by Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, especially in our Gaudiya Vaishnava Sampradaya, because in separation from Krishna, one feels intense mood of service to Krishna, not as much as when one is in the presence of Krishna. It is more intense than in the presence of Krishna. In separation from Krishna, one is able to serve with more intensity Krishna, with that intense feeling of devotion towards Krishna. There are many incidents recorded by biographers about his preaching. Even though he is called a bhajananandi, he would not travel and actively preach, but anybody approached him for getting guidance, for getting some practical instructions, he was ever willing to give them his divine association. So I will just mention one or two such incidents which are very instructive for all of us. Once a lawyer by name Bhattacharya brought several sweets and prayerfully requested Srila Gautishwada's Babaji Maharaj to accept his offering. Srila Babaji Maharaj told him, "I never take any sweets." So then Bhattacharya replied, "There is nothing higher than accepting food that the Lord has directly accepted," indicating thereby that it is Prasadam. "Why are you refusing Prasadam?" So then Srila Babaji Maharaj, Gautishwada's Babaji Maharaj, sharply retorted, "Whoever eats fish is like a prostitute." These are harsh words, but then they are required to cut through the several layers of illusion that is clouding the consciousness of our condition. So if someone has perverted desires and offers foodstuffs to Lord Chaitanya, these preparations can never be accepted

after some time, however, when he was very much distressed in his mind, he decided to go and see Babaji Maharaj. So Srila Gaukishodas Babaji Maharaj could immediately understand the reason for the depression of this particular seeker, and he told him, "You have left the association of devotees where topics about Krishna are discussed, and now you are living in a secluded place performing solitary worship of Krishna. When one hears the topic of Supreme Lord in the company of devotees, then one becomes freed from Maya's net of illusion, but if someone performs worship of the Lord in a secluded place, not in the association of devotees, one becomes caught by the material illusory energy of the Lord. As a consequence, instead of topics about the Supreme Lord possessing the heart, mundane subject matters will occupy the heart." The seeker replied, "I thought it better to reside in a secluded place and perform my own individual worship than to become disturbed by hearing the sharp words of a sadhu." He thought, "If I remain with a sadhu and the sadhu speaks very harsh words, then my mind will always be disturbed. I can peacefully go to some other place and do my own worship and be nicely situated to do devotional service." So Babaji Maharaj replied, "Please take note that these sadhus who speak sharp words to drive away the witch of the illusory energy are actually the only real devotees of Krishna and friends of the living entities. if one does not attain the spiritual energy given by chanting the holy name, then one will become attracted by his wife and children. That day at sunrise, his disciple Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Saraswati Thakur left Sri Mayapur for the place where Srila Bhaktisiddhanta, sorry, Gaur Kishore das Babaji Maharaj had been staying in a place at Kuliyam. Jeeva Goswami has explained the genealogical history of Sri Rupa Goswami's family. They were the descendants of Sarvagya Satguru, a great scholar of the Vedas. He was an expert in Yajur Veda. Sri Sarvagya was a Brahmin and also one of the kings of Karnataka in the 12th century Shakabdha. In his lineage appeared a great devotee named Kumara Deva who had settled in Jaishur, Bangladesh. He got married to a very chaste lady named Revati Devi.

#### incarnation, devotion, spiritual identity
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/sDOmqVy2GoY?t=60
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Sri Rupa Goswami was none other than the incarnation of Sri Rupa Manjari, one of the chief assistants of Lalitha Sakhi, one of the eight principal gopis of Vrindavan."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the identities of Rupa, Sanatana, and Jiva Goswamis as incarnations of eternal associates of Krishna, emphasizing their spiritual significance.

In the course of time, Kumara Deva and Revati Devi gave birth to many sons. Most illustrious among them were Amara, later known as Sanatana Goswami, Santosha, known as Rupa Goswami and Vallabha, known as Anupama. It is believed that Sanatana was born around 1488 AD, while his younger brother Rupa appeared in this world around 1493 AD. Krishnadas Kaviraj Goswami mentions in the Adi Leela of Sri Chaitanya Charitamrita that Sri Rupa, Sanatana and Anupama are the 43rd, 44th and 45th branches of Mahaprabhu's Desire Tree of devotion service and that they are the best of all. Anupama Vallabha Sri Rupa Sanatana etina shakha vrkshera paschime sarvottama. Sri Kavikarnapura reveals in Gauraganodesha Deepika that Sri Rupa Goswami was none other than the incarnation of Sri Rupa Manjari, one of the chief assistants of Lalitha Sakhi, one of the eight principal gopis of Vrindavan. Sri Sanatana Goswami was the combined incarnation of Rati Manjari and Lavanga Manjari and Sanatana Kumara. Jiva Goswami, the son of Anupama, was the incarnation of Ilaasa Manjari.

**Summary:** This segment narrates how the three brothers settled in Malda, became attractive figures in society, and were eventually pressured by Nawab Hussain Shah to become ministers.

After Kumara Deva had died, these three brothers came over and settled here at Malda, where they continued with their studies. As they grew up, they became exceptionally attractive to all of the society. They possessed beautiful bodily features, noble character and natural compassion towards every living being. They were embodiments of the Lord's love. These three brothers studied the science of logic, Nyaya, and the knowledge of the divine. They were also the descendants of Madhusudana Vachaspati, who was the brother of Sarvabhauma Bhattacharya. They also became proficient in Sanskrit, Arabic and Persian. When Sanatana Goswami was very young, he saw a dream in which a Brahmin gave him a copy of Srimad Bhagavatam. The next day, to his surprise, he indeed received Srimad Bhagavatam. From then on, Shri Sanatana began scrutinizingly studying Srimad Bhagavatam, leaving aside all other scriptures. Bengal, during that time, was under the Mughal rule of Nawab Hussain Shah. He is the same king who had employed Shri Mukunda Dasa of Shrikhanda as his personal doctor. Seeing the popularity of Shri Rupa and Sanatana amongst the great general populace, the Nawab decided to employ them as his ministers. In this way, he planned to bring the entire Hindu population under his control. If Rupa and Sanatana joined him, then his subjects would become more submissive, he thought. On the other hand, he notified Shri Rupa and Sanatana, telling them that if they became the ministers, he would award the Vaishnavas and Hindus with all freedom. Instead, if they did not accept his proposal, then he would torture and prosecute the masses.

**Summary:** This segment describes Rupa and Sanatana's exemplary service as ministers, their subsequent excommunication, and their accumulation of wealth, despite maintaining a mood of separation from the Lord.

Hearing the king's warning, Shri Rupa, Sanatana and Anupama reluctantly agreed to serve the king. Their service was so exemplary that Shri Sanatana Goswami was made the Prime Minister of Bengal and Rupa Goswami was made the Home Minister. Due to their close proximity with the Muslims, the two brothers were excommunicated from the Hindu society by the orthodox caste Brahmins of Gaur Mandala. Thus, Shri Rupa Goswami came to be known as Dabarkhas and Shri Sanatana as Sakaramalik. The king grew very fond of them and considered them his own brothers. He awarded them with tremendous amounts of wealth and power. They settled down here at Ramkeli in Malda, where they constructed beautiful opulent palaces and gardens that served as a replica of Vruddhavan. Being pure devotees, Rupa and Sanatana always lived in the mood of separation from the Lord and his abode. Here at Ramkeli, the beautiful temples and ponds dug by our Goswamis are still present. The beautiful deity of Shri Madana Mohana that was installed by them over here continues to accept our humble services till this day.

Lord Chaitanya, during his second attempt to reach Vruddhavan, decided to take a roundabout route. All of them were surcharged with deep ecstatic feelings, completely devoid of external consciousness and surrendering themselves completely. They sang and danced along. An ocean of love flooded the people with waves after waves of ecstasy. As the procession reached new places, more people joined. Wherever the Lord touched the ground with his lotus feet, people immediately gathered to take the dust. The people took out so much dirt that holes were created in the ground. Performing Sankirtana over here, the Lord danced and sometimes lost his consciousness out of intense love of God. When Nawab Hussain Shah came to know that Lord Chaitanya was attracting so much attention, he was astonished. His spies informed him how Mahaprabhu had immersed everyone in a wave of transcendental ecstasy. He learned how the people, irrespective of their caste, creed or religion, were raising their hands and engaging in the congregational chanting of Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna, Krishna Krishna, Hare Hare, Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare. So the Nawab then asked Keshava Chhatri whether he knew anything about Lord Chaitanya. Keshava, in spite of knowing everything, tried to diplomatically downplay the situation. He replied that Chaitanya Deva was simply a touring mendicant and that only a few people had come to see him. He warned the King against considering the advice of his spies too seriously. After pacifying the King in this way, Keshava sent a Brahmana messenger to Lord Chaitanya, requesting him to leave without delay. The King then inquired from Rupa Goswami Dabarkas and asked his opinion. Rupa Goswami glorified Sri Chaitanya and revealed that he was none other than the Supreme Personality of God and Himself. He added that it was the Nawab's great fortune that the Lord has chosen to descend and manifest his pastime in this country. It was only by Mahaprabhu's mercy that the Nawab was enlightened. The Nawab was successful and victorious in all his affairs. The Nawab agreed with Rupa Goswami and remarked that he would perceive in his mind as well that Lord Chaitanya was none other than his worshipable God.

Thus, in the dead of the night, the two brothers went to meet the Lord. First, they met Nityananda Prabhu and Haridas Dhaka who introduced them to Sri Gaurahari. Out of great humility, the two brothers held straw between their teeth and fell down like a rod before Mahaprabhu. They were so overwhelmed that they began crying in joy. They introduced themselves as the lowest of men who were employed in the worst kind of employment. They glorified the Lord as Patitapavana, the deliverer of the fallen, and assured him that none in the world qualified as being more fallen than them. Out of sheer humility, they declared themselves millions of times more fallen than even Jagai and Madai, the sinful brothers whom Lord Chaitanya had previously delivered. Jagai and Madai are millions of times more virtuous. Adhamma and Patita are sinners. We are two people. Thus, they tried to establish themselves as the befitting candidates upon which Lord Chaitanya should shower his costless mercy. Hearing their prayers, Lord Chaitanya became very pleased and blessed them wholeheartedly. He then revealed that the two brothers were his eternal servants. Mahaprabhu also informed them that he had received several of their letters, which reflected their humble state of mind and consciousness. He accepted them and awarded them the name Rupa unto Dhabi's caste and Sanatana unto Sakara-Malik.

#### refusal, arrest, escape, divine protection

**Summary:** This segment narrates Sanatana Goswami's refusal to obey the king's order, his subsequent arrest, and his eventual escape with the help of the money provided by Rupa Goswami.

Meanwhile, Sanatana Goswami stopped going to the office and would just remain at home reading and chanting Srimad Bhagavatam all day. In the assembly of devotees, Nawab Hussain Shah came to his residence to enquire about Sanatana's health as he thought he was sick. Seeing that he was perfectly fit, the Nawab asked Sanatana to assist him in attacking the province of Orissa. Sanatana Goswami refused to obey the order of the king and expressed his desire to retire from service instead. The king became enraged and ordered Sanatana's arrest. Using the money that Rupa Goswami had kept for him, Sanatana Goswami managed to bribe the jailer and somehow escaped. The jailer was initially reluctant to release him, but 7,000 gold coins were enough to change his position. On being released, Sanatana immediately crossed over the Ganges and fled. He passed through hilly terrains and spent the night at a small hotel on his way to Benares. The hotel owner, knowing that Sanatana's servant Isha had eight gold coins in his possession, wanted to murder both of them and take away the money. However, Isha could guess the evil plans of the hotel owner and voluntarily offered him the coins and sought his help to safely reach his destination. Thus, the owner helped them cross the hilly track and proceed towards Varanasi.

#### meeting at Prayag, instruction, empowerment, mission
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/sDOmqVy2GoY?t=1031
**Verse References:** —

**Key Quote:** "Lord Chaitanya embraced the two brothers and placed his feet upon the head."
**Summary:** This segment describes Rupa and Anupama's meeting with Lord Chaitanya at Prayag, where the Lord instructed and empowered Rupa Goswami in the philosophy of devotional service and assigned him a mission in Vrindavan.

The two brothers, Rupa and Anupama, meanwhile, met with Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu at Prayag, Allahabad. The two of them had straws between their teeth and surrendered themselves at the lotus feet of the Lord. Lord Chaitanya embraced the two brothers and placed his feet upon the head. It was here at Prayag, at the Dvadasva Medha Ghat, that Lord Chaitanya had instructed Sri Rupa Goswami for ten days, empowering him in the philosophy of devotional service. He taught Rupa the limit of Krishna Tattva, Bhakti Tattva, the truth regarding the transcendental mellows, culminating in conjugal love between Radha and Krishna, Krishna Tattva, Bhakti Tattva, Rasa Tattva, Pranata. He also taught him the ultimate conclusions of Srimad Bhagavatam. By entering into Rupa's heart, Mahaprabhu empowered him to ascertain the conclusions of all truth. Teaching him thus, Lord Chaitanya sent Rupa Goswami to Vrindavan, instructing him to excavate the holy places of Krishna's pastimes, discover the ancient deities that lay hidden in the Vrindavan and reinstall them in his temples, write transcendental pieces of literature and preach the Vrindavan way of worship to the entire world.

#### teachings of Lord Chaitanya, qualities of a Vaishnava, literary contributions, essence of scriptures
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/sDOmqVy2GoY?t=1127
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Bhakti Rasamata Sindhu contains the essence of all the revealed scriptures."
**Summary:** This segment summarizes Lord Chaitanya's teachings, highlights the qualities of a Vaishnava, and lists the significant literary contributions of Rupa and Sanatana Goswamis, emphasizing their expertise in extracting the essence of scriptures.

The summary of Lord Chaitanya's teaching to Rupa Goswami has been summarized by Srila Rupa in the teachings of Lord Chaitanya. So those who want to read more about the teachings can read the teachings of Lord Chaitanya or Chaitanya Charitamrita. It is said that Lord Chaitanya had taught the four principal qualities of a Vaishnava through four of his intimate associates. He had taught the quality of self-control through the life and examples of Ramananda Raya, the quality of neutrality through Damodara Pandita who even scolded Mahaprabhu at times, the aspect of tolerance through Haridas Thakur and the quality of humility through Sanatana Goswami. Among the books that Shri Sanatana Goswami had written, Hari Bhakti Vilas and Brihat Vaishnava Toshani are significant. Amongst the books composed by Shri Rupa Goswami, Hamsa Dutta, Uddhava Sandesha, Krishna Janma Tithi Vidhi, Radha Krishna Ganodesha Deepika, Sthava Mala, Vidakta Madhava, Lalita Madhava, Dhanakeli Kaumotuki, Bhakti Rasamata Sindhu, Ujjvala Neelamani, Akshyata Chandrika, Mathura Mahima, Padhyavali, Nataka Chandrika, and Laghu Bhagavata Amrita are the most significant. Bhakti Rasamata Sindhu contains the essence of all the revealed scriptures. Shri Srinivas Acharya in his prayers unto the six Goswamis hence glorifies them as expert in extracting the essence of all the revealed scriptures with the aim of establishing the Jeeva in his eternal position of performing pure devotional service unto Krishna.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/jsbOXtHRf6Y?t=64
**Verse References:** —

**Summary:** This segment discusses Sanatana Goswami's humility and self-identification as fallen due to association with materialistic individuals, emphasizing the importance of surrendering to Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu for salvation from sinful reactions.

Text 98: Putting a straw in his mouth and bowing down, Sanatana Goswami clasped the lotus feet of Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu and humbly spoke as follows. Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Shri Prabhupada. Translation: Sanatana Goswami said, "I was born in a low family and my associates are all low class men. I myself am fallen and am the lowest of men. Indeed, I have passed my whole life fallen in the well of sinful materialism." Actually, Shri Sanatana Goswami belonged to a brahmana family because he belonged to the Saraswati division of the brahmanas and was well-cultured and well-educated. Somehow or other, he accepted a ministership in the Muslim government. Therefore, he had to associate with meat-eaters, drunkards, and gross materialists. Sanatana Goswami considered himself fallen, for in the association of such men, he also fell victim to material enjoyment. Having passed his life in that way, he considered that he had wasted his valuable time. This statement about how one can become fallen in this material world is made by the greatest authority in the Gaudiya Vaishnavasampradaya. Actually, the whole world is presently fallen into material existence. Everyone is a meat-eater, drunkard, woman-hunter, gambler, and what not. People are enjoying material life by committing the four basic sins. Although they are fallen, if they simply submit themselves at the lotus feet of Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, they will be saved from sinful reactions.

Here is a dog, a street dog, and here is a learned brāhmaṇa. But one who is pundit, one who is Kṛṣṇa conscious, he sees that the pundit and the dog, they are the same, because they are also the same spiritual part. By his karma, he has become a learned pundit. And by his karma, he has become a dog.

**Summary:** Srila Prabhupada explains the three phases of understanding the Absolute Truth: Brahman, Paramatma, and Bhagavan, culminating in Krishna as the Supreme Personality of Godhead, and contrasts Aryan and non-Aryan values.

of life, they do not lead to higher planets but to infamy, report by Shila Prabhupada. Krishna and the Supreme Personality of Godhead are identical; therefore, Lord Krishna is referred to as Bhagawan throughout the Gita. Bhagawan is the ultimate in the Absolute Truth. Absolute Truth is realized in three phases of understanding, namely Brahman, or the impersonal all-pervasive spirit; Paramatma, or the centralized aspect of the Supreme within the heart of all living entities; and Bhagawan, or the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Krishna. In the Srimad Bhagavatam, this conception of the Absolute Truth is explained thus: vadanti tattva vidas tattvam yajnana madhvayam brahmeti paramatmeti bhagavaneti shabdhyate. The Absolute Truth is realized in three phases of understanding by the knower of the Absolute Truth, and all of them are identical. Such phases of the Absolute Truth are expressed as Brahman, Paramatma, and Bhagawan. These three Divine aspects can be explained by the example of the sun, which also has three different aspects, namely the sunshine, the sun's surface, and the sun planet itself. One who studies the sunshine only is the preliminary student; one who understands the sun's surface is further advanced; and one who can enter into the sun planet is the highest. Ordinary students who are satisfied by simply understanding the sunshine, its universal pervasiveness, and the glaring effulgence of its impersonal nature may be compared to those who can realize only the Brahman feature of the Absolute Truth. The student who has advanced still further can know the sun disc, which is compared to knowledge of the Paramatma feature of the Absolute Truth, and the student who can enter into the heart of the Sun planet is compared to those who realize the personal features of the Supreme Absolute Truth. Therefore, the bhaktas, or the transcendentalists, who have realized the Bhagawan feature of the Absolute Truth are the topmost transcendentalists. Although all students who are engaged in the study of the Absolute Truth are engaged in the same subject matter, the sunshine, the sun disc, and the inner affairs of the Sun planet cannot be separated from one another, and yet the students of the three different phases are not in the same category. The Sanskrit word Bhagawan is explained by the great authority Parashara Muni, the father of Vyasa Deva: the Supreme personality who possesses all riches, all strength, all fame, all beauty, all knowledge, and all renunciation is called Bhagawan. There are many persons who are very rich, very powerful, very beautiful, very famous, very learned, and very much detached, but no one can claim that he possesses all riches, all strength, etc., entirely. Only Krishna can claim this because he is the Supreme Personality of Godhead. No living entity, including Brahma, Lord Shiva, or Narayana, can possess as fully as Krishna. Therefore, it is concluded in the Brahma Samhita by Lord Brahma himself that Lord Krishna is the Supreme Personality of Godhead. No one is equal to or above him. He is the primeval Lord, or Bhagawan, known as Govinda, and he is the supreme cause of all causes. There are many personalities possessing the qualities of Bhagawan, but Krishna is the Supreme because none can excel him. He is the Supreme person, and his body is eternal, full of knowledge, and Bliss. He is the Primeval Lord Govinda and the cause of all causes. In the Bhagavatam also, there is a list of many incarnations of the Supreme Personality of Godhead, but Krishna is described as the original Personality of Godhead from whom many, many incarnations and personalities of Godhead expand. Krishna is the one who is eternal and full of knowledge and bliss; he is the Supreme personality whom many incarnations and personalities of Godhead expand. इंद्राहारी व्याकुलम लोकम रदयन्ति युगे युगे All the lists of the incarnations of Godhead submitted herewith are either plenary expansions or parts of the plenary expansions of the Supreme Godhead, but Krishna is the Supreme Personality of Godhead Himself. Therefore, Krishna is the original Supreme Personality of Godhead, the Absolute Truth, the source of both the Supersoul and the Impersonal Brahman. In the presence of the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Arjuna's lamentation for his kinsmen is certainly unbecoming, and therefore Krishna expressed His surprise with the word, कुतस, wherefrom? Such unmanly sentiments were never expected from a person belonging to the civilized class of men known as Aryans. The word Aryan is applicable to persons who know the value of life and have a civilization based on spiritual realization. Persons who are led by the material conception of life do not know that the aim of life is really to achieve the goal of life. They are led by the realization of the Absolute Truth, Vishnu or Bhagavan, and they are captivated by the external features of the material world, and therefore they do not know what liberation is. Persons who have no knowledge of liberation from material bondage are called non-Aryans. Although Arjuna was a Kshatriya, he was deviating from his prescribed duties by declining to fight. This act of cowardice is described as befitting the non-Aryans. Such deviation from duty does not help one in the program, nor does it even give one the opportunity to become famous in this world. Lord Krishna did not approve of the so-called compassion of Arjuna for his kinsmen.

One who gives initiation, which is Shaila Prabhupada, and the other one who officiates, which is the Rithvik. So, when Satswaroop Dasa asked what is the relationship of the person who gives initiation, and the disciple, Shaila Prabhupada immediately said that he is Guru. What does that mean? The person who is giving initiation, the initiator is the Guru. And the officiator is the Rithvik. Initiator is Shaila Prabhupada and he is Guru. It is very clear, abundantly clear. Now, in the second part of this session, of this conversation, of this reply, Satswaroop Dasa and Tamalkrishna Goswami wanted to clearly know if the disciples are theirs or Shaila Prabhupada's. So, the first part of the reply did not yield the response they were looking for. So, they wanted to see if they can eke out something which they were looking for. Because, in the first part of this reply, Prabhupada only spoke about the principle, Amarajnaya Guruhaya and all that. So, Satswaroop Dasa wanted to clarify. So, Satswaroop, so they may also be considered your disciples. Prabhupada, yes, they are disciples. Why consider who? Tamalkrishna intervened. No, he is asking that these Rithvik Acharyas, they are officiating, giving Diksha. There, the people who they give Diksha to, whose disciple are they? So, you have to understand this question by Tamalkrishna Goswami. Here, Tamalkrishna Goswami sensed the difference in understanding between Satswaroop Dasa and Shaila Prabhupada. When Satswaroop Dasa asked, what is the relationship of the person who gives initiation, he was referring to the officiator, the Rithvik. But Prabhupada, he referred to the initiator, which was himself. So, Tamalkrishna Goswami understood. Hence, the July 9th directive to carry out initiations in ISKCON is not some temporary order. It is the final order of Srila Prabhupada and ISKCON must follow it. Vishwaguru Srila Prabhupada ki jai. **Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/-ZjWL2a5c6E?t=259
**Verse References:** BG 2.47
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "What meets our eyes is a superficial understanding."
**Summary:** The speaker discusses the apparent contradiction of the Lord exhibiting anger when the scriptures advise against it, emphasizing the importance of understanding scriptures through parampara to avoid superficial interpretations.

For someone who is totally new to Krishna Consciousness, this can be bewildering. How can the Lord get angry? Krishna in the Bhagavad Gita Himself says there are three gates leading to hell: lust, anger, and greed. And here the Lord Himself is getting angry. This is Jaisa Achar and then Prachar. So here the Lord is getting angry and grew more and more enraged at the smell of blood of His person. In His eagerness to win, this we see. Okay, actually this can be expected, after all He was a demon, eagerness to win. And Krishna also says you have the right to do your duty but do not be attached to the results. On one side the Lord says control the senses, control the mind. From the very beginning control the senses, and then He marries 16,108 queens. So people sometimes even ask this question: Why the Lord married so many queens? From their understanding, was He not satisfied with one wife? Why did He dance with the gopis? That's why Krishna in the Bhagavad Gita says, what meets our eyes is a superficial understanding. That's why Krishna says, it's a most confidential knowledge. Tatvatah means in truth. What we can understand just by reading like a novel or a comic or any other book, will not be tatvatah understanding. It will not be the real understanding. That's why Krishna says one who understands in tatvatah, in truth, he gets eligible for liberation from the cycle of birth and death. He goes back to the kingdom of God. So how do we understand? Why the Lord who is... And we also understand saintly people are expected to be tolerant, not get provoked. They should be peaceful. They should be equipoised. They should be forgiving. These are all qualities of devotees and Lord should also exhibit these qualities. And here we are saying that the Lord is fighting and Lord is getting angry and is beating Hiranaksha and is eager to win, to defeat Hiranaksha. So how do we understand this? So as I mentioned, if we have not studied the scriptures in a parampara, a parampara understanding, just like Prabhupada is writing the purports, when we read those purports and understand them, all our misconceptions and wrong understandings slowly can get wiped away. Typical understanding is a saintly person means he should never get angry. That's why many times people say Hinduism, because of all this tolerance and ahimsa, that's why these Mohammedans invaded India and we were just simply tolerant and they ransacked the temples, destroyed the temples. And we were all talking about ahimsa, we should be tolerant. Actually that's not the correct understanding. Wherever anger is required, it has to be exhibited. Wherever ahimsa is required, it has to be done. The whole Bhagavad Gita was spoken by Lord to Arjuna to inspire him to fight. Sometimes it can be bewildering what to tolerate, what not to tolerate, when to get angry, when not to get angry. There is a very famous quote which says, not to get angry is very easy. If someone decides I'll not get angry, relatively it's easy. A stone also does not get angry. But to get angry at the right time, in the right circumstances, on the right person, to the right degree, is not very easy. In other words, there is place of anger, there is place for every emotion. The emotions what we exhibit, originally is there in the Lord. Lord is a person, and person means emotions, feelings. And every emotion has a place. Just like Hanuman got angry, and he burned the Lanka. He was a great devotee of the Lord. Everyone worships Hanuman. He worships Hanuman, as a great devotee of the Lord. And he got angry, and he burned the Lanka. And still we glorify him, still we worship him. And still we accept him as a great devotee of the Lord. So many times, people have a very superficial understanding of our scriptures. In fact, many people who come up with these arguments, may not have even read the scriptures. Or if they would have read, they would have read very superficially, some thing written by some author, and they miss out the correct understanding.

Devotional service does not change but the devotee changes, the devotee improves. Prabhupada gives wonderful example here in the purport. The example of mango can be given here. If one gets an unripe mango, it is still a mango. And when it is ripe it remains the same mango. But it has become more tasteful and relishable. When the mango becomes ripe it will be sweet, delicious, tasteful, relishable. Similarly, there is devotional service performed according to the directions of the spiritual master and injunctions and regulative principles of Shastra. That is Vaidhi Bhakti or Sadhana Bhakti. And there is devotional service in the spiritual world rendered directly in association with the Supreme Personality of Godhead. But they are both the same. There is no change. The difference is that one stage is unripe the other stage is ripe and more relishable.

### Why Our Senses Fail to Reveal Truth | Sri Amitasana Dasa | ISKCON Bangalore Sanga
**Speaker:** HG Amitasana Dasa

#### limitations of senses, spiritual knowledge, surrender, humility, perception of reality
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Lxx7DF7xBbM?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Our scriptures are saying that we cannot perceive the reality with our senses because our senses, we all have four inherent defects."
**Summary:** The speaker discusses the limitations of our senses in perceiving reality, referencing scientific theories about extra dimensions and emphasizing the need for spiritual knowledge, humility, and surrender to a spiritual master to gain a glimpse of reality.

I'll share with you a quote from a very eminent scientist. He says, "All the scientific theories do not dictate that there has to be only three dimensions. Although we can't see with our eyes or feel with our fingers, additional dimensions of space are a logical possibility. Our senses register only three dimensions. So, extra dimensions might sound incredible. Even the dimension in the world we are living in, the Earth planet we are living in, in Hyderabad city what we are living in, what we are seeing is not necessarily complete reality. Forget about where we have not gone. But our scriptures are saying that we cannot perceive the reality with our senses because our senses, we all have four inherent defects. So, with this limitation, inherent defects in our senses, we will never be able to perceive the reality. So, when we get spiritual knowledge, we understand how small, insignificant we are, coupled with humility. I am a small, insignificant Jeeva. I have limited sense perception. Can't even control myself. How can I control things?" When that living entity develops that humility, surrenders to the Supreme Lord, surrenders to a bona fide spiritual master, OM AGYANATI MIRAN DASYA GYANANJANA SHALAKE, we open our eyes with the torch of knowledge.

#### renunciation, search for truth, early life
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/ZW4CAbe8Xuw?t=0
**Verse References:** BG 7.16

**Summary:** The speaker describes his early life, including his rebellion against the system he was raised in, his becoming a vegetarian, and his search for the absolute truth, mentioning the three types of people who come to Krishna according to the Bhagavad Gita.

I guess it began when I was 12 years old. Now I'm 70, and without knowing in this life, without the knowledge of what is Krishna consciousness, what was Srila Prabhupada, at the age of 12, somehow or another, I rebelled against the system which I was brought up into. I became a vegetarian. I started searching for the absolute truth. The Bhagavad Gita tells us that three types of persons come to Krishna: those who are seeking money, those who are in distress, and those who are seeking the absolute truth. So I don't think I fell into the category of those who were seeking money, because I had a lot of that, and I gave it all up. It was self-made, but some help from the parents and the family. And distress, yes, we were all in distress in this material world. We didn't know which way to go, what to do, our seemingly happiness with our material life, but actually seeking the absolute truth. I was looking in the mountains, I was looking in the forests, I was looking in the swamps, I was living in the ghettos with the black people, I was prompting with kings, I was living rich, I was living poor, I was traveling from place to place, with vows of poverty, trying to understand.

I want to be independent of Krishna. I want to be independent of Krishna. Krishna. Just like sunlight has come from sun, we are also Jeeva Shakti coming from Krishna, the Shaktimaan. But the difference is that is a inert, lifeless energy, light energy, heat energy. Whereas we are a Shakti which has got Chetana, consciousness. And this Chetana Shakti, Chit Shakti has developed a desire because it's Chetana. Chetana means has desire, has thinking, feeling. It means a kind of a force in the body. Prabhupada gives the example, just like our body is designed in such a way, when there is a nature's call, it creates a force, irresistible force. We all have to rush to the washroom. In the same way, there are other forces in this body, and one of them is the force of the mind. As spiritualists, we must know these workings of the mind, workings of the forces in this body, so that we know how to deal with them. Shukadev Goswami is giving one such example. He is saying, "This mind, which is unsteady and which comes with a force, don't trust this mind." This is the first instruction. So, Prabhupada explains, as spiritualists, we do not trust our mind, meaning we do not surrender to the dictations of our mind. The mind comes with a force. Mind comes with an idea: "Let's do this. Let's do that. You do this. You do that." And it comes with a certain force. Don't trust your mind. This is the instruction. Watch the mind's action. So, in other words, this is the instruction. #### devotional service, impediments, Vaishnava Aparadha, Krishna consciousness
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/i5ImCRHRxU8?t=126

**Key Quote:** "Krishna consciousness is perfect and eternal, and therefore it cannot be lost under any circumstances."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the impediments to devotional service, including Vaishnava Aparadha and the Lord's desire, emphasizing that a devotee advanced in Krishna consciousness cannot be lost.

who has once absorbed his mind in the glories of the Supreme Personality of Godhead may sometimes be influenced by impediments, but he still does not give up his exalted devotional position. According to Srila Vishwanath Chakravarthy Thakura, there are two kinds of impediments to devotional service. The first is an offense at the lotus feet of a Vaishnava. This is called Vaishnava Aparadha. Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu warned His devotees not to commit Vaishnava Aparadha, which He described as the mad elephant offense. When a mad elephant enters a beautiful garden, it destroys everything, leaving a barren field. Similarly, the power of Vaishnava Aparadha is so great that even an advanced devotee becomes almost devoid of his spiritual assets if he commits it. Since Krishna consciousness is eternal, it cannot be destroyed altogether, but advancement may be checked for the time being. Thus, Vaishnava Aparadha is one kind of impediment to devotional service. Sometimes, however, the Supreme Personality of Godhead or His devotee desires to impede one's devotional service. For example, Hiranyakashyapu and Hiranyakshya were formerly Jaya and Vijaya, the gatekeepers in Vaikuntha, but by the desire of the Lord, they became His enemies for three lives. Thus, the desire of the Lord is another kind of impediment. But in both cases, the pure devotee once advanced in Krishna consciousness cannot be lost. Following the orders of his superiors, Swayambhuva and Lord Brahma, Priyavrata accepted family life, but this did not mean he lost his position in devotional service. Krishna consciousness is perfect and eternal, and therefore it cannot be lost under any circumstances. Because the material world is full of obstructions to advancement in Krishna consciousness, there may appear to be many impediments, yet Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, declares in Bhagavad Gita, 9.31 Once one has taken shelter at the lotus feet of the Lord, he cannot be lost. In this verse, the word Shivatamam is very significant. Shivatamam means the most auspicious. The devotional path is so auspicious that a devotee cannot be lost under any circumstances. This is described in the Srimad Bhagavad Gita by the Lord Himself. Parthnaivehanamutra Vinashastasya Vidyavrata My dear Arjuna, for a devotee, there is no question of being lost, either in this life or in the next. In Bhagavad Gita, 6.43, the Lord clearly explains how this is so. Tatratam buddhi samyogam labhate pavarvadehikam yadate chatato bhuyaha samsiddho kuru nandana By the order of the Lord, a perfect devotee sometimes comes to this material world like an ordinary human being. Because of his previous practice, such a perfect devotee naturally becomes a devotee. He becomes attached to devotional service, apparently without cause. Despite all kinds of impediments due to surrounding circumstances, he automatically perseveres in devotional service and gradually advances until he once again becomes perfect. Below Mangal Thakura had been an advanced devotee in his previous life, but in his next life he became greatly fallen and was attached to a prostitute. Suddenly, however, his entire behavior was changed by the words of the very prostitute, who had so much attracted him, and he became a great devotee. In the lives of exalted devotees, there are many such instances, proving that once one has taken to the shelter of the lotus feet of the Lord, he cannot be lost. Kaunteya pratijanihi namey bhaktav pranashyati The fact is, however, that one becomes a devotee when he is completely freed from all reactions to sinful life. As Krishna states in Bhagavad Gita, 7.28, Esham tuantagatam paapam jananam punyakam te dvandhva moha nirmukta bhajan teman dhrdha vrataah Persons who have acted piously in previous lives and in this life, whose sinful actions are completely eradicated and who are freed from the duality of illusion, engage themselves in my service with determination. On the other hand, as Prahlad Maharaj said, Matirna krishne paratas svatova mito bhipadyeta grihavrataana A person who is too attached to materialistic things, family life, home, family, wife, children and so on, cannot develop Krishna consciousness. These apparent contradictions are resolved in the life of a devotee by the grace of the Supreme Lord and therefore a devotee is never bereft of his position on the path of liberation which is Both Arjuna and Lord Shri Krishna are described here in an angry mood. But Arjuna's eyes were like balls of red copper, whereas the eyes of the Lord were like lotuses. His anger is not like the anger of a conditioned living being within the modes of qualitative material nature. Because he is absolute, both his anger and pleasure are the same. His anger is not exhibited in the three modes of material nature. It is only a sign of his bent of mind towards the cause of his devotee. Because that is his transcendental nature. Therefore, even if he is angry, the object of anger is blessed. He is unchanged in all circumstances.

#### renunciation, Krishna consciousness, anger, liberation, sense control
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/HdPMySPtJv4?t=103
**Verse References:** BG 9.22
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Becoming liberated does not necessitate losing one's sensual activities; sense activities continue even in the liberated stage."
**Summary:** The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's purport, focusing on the role of a sanyasi, Krishna as the best friend, the nature of anger in liberated souls, and the continuation of sense activities in Krishna consciousness.

Purport by Srila Prabhupada According to the Vedic system, a sanyasi, a person in the renounced order of life, is dressed in saffron-colored garments. This saffron dress is practically a passport for the mendicant and sanyasi to go anywhere. The sanyasi's duty is to enlighten people in Krishna consciousness. Those in the renounced order of life have no other business but preaching the glories and supremacy of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Therefore, the Vedic sociological conception is that a sanyasi should not be restricted. He is allowed to go anywhere and everywhere he wants, and he is not refused any gift he might demand from a householder. The four Kumaras came to see the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Narayana. The word Suhrtama, best of all friends, is important. As Lord Krishna states in the Bhagavad Gita, He is the best friend of all living entities. suhrtam sarva-bhuta-anam No one can be a greater well-wishing friend to any living entity than the Supreme Personality of Godhead. He is so kindly disposed towards everyone that in spite of our completely forgetting our relationship with the Supreme Lord, He comes Himself. Sometimes personally, as Lord Krishna appeared on this earth, and sometimes as His devotee, as did Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, and sometimes He sends His bona fide devotees to reclaim all the fallen souls. Therefore, He is the greatest well-wishing friend of everyone. And the Kumaras wanted to see Him. The doorkeepers should have known that the four sages had no other business, and therefore to restrict them from entering the palace was not apt. In this verse, it is figuratively stated that the younger brother of desire suddenly appeared in person when the sages were forbidden to see their most beloved personality of Godhead. The younger brother of desire is anger. If one's desire is not fulfilled, the younger brother anger follows. Here we can mark that even great saintly persons like the Kumaras were also angry, but they were not angry for their personal interests. They were angry because they were forbidden to enter the palace to see the personality of Godhead. Therefore, the theory that in the perfectional stage one should not have anger is not supported in this verse. Anger will continue even in the liberated stage. These four mendicant brothers, the Kumaras, were considered liberated persons, but still they were angry because they were restricted in their service to the Lord. The difference between the anger of an ordinary person and that of a liberated person is that an ordinary person becomes angry because his sense desires are not being fulfilled. Whereas a liberated person like the Kumaras becomes angry when restricted in the discharge of duties for serving the Supreme Personality of Godhead. In the previous verse, it has been clearly mentioned that the Kumaras were liberated persons. Vidit Atma Tatva means one who understands the truth of self-realization. One who does not understand the truth of self-realization is called ignorant. But one who understands the self, the super-self, their inter-relation and activities in self-realization is called Vidit Atma Tatva. Although the Kumaras were already liberated persons, they nevertheless became angry. This point is very important. Becoming liberated does not necessitate losing one's sensual activities. Sense activities continue even in the liberated stage. The difference is however that sense activities in liberation are accepted only in connection with Krishna Consciousness. Whereas sense activities in the conditioned stage are enacted for personal sense gratification.

In another place, in the Bhagavatam, King Vena was a very impious king. But King Vena was not a good king. He was a sinful person and he didn't care for the brahmanas and he was not encouraging any spiritual activities in his kingdom. At that time, all the brahmanas in his kingdom come together and they discuss what is to be done. And they decide that they should kill King Vena. And they kill him. And then, it says, from Vena's body they created another person and made him the king. Now the question comes, if the brahmanas were so powerful that they could kill and dethrone a king, why couldn't they become the king themselves? After dethroning King Vena, because after all he was a bad king. And there Prabhupada explains, no, the brahmanas would not become the king because they had more important duties than becoming a king, which is, they were engaged in self-realization and they were engaged in teaching others in the society in the matter of self-realization. So you see from all of these kind of instructions, where Srila Prabhupada positions that activity of giving knowledge about self-realization is. It's even far superior and more important than becoming a king and ruling over a kingdom. So this is the kind of conception that Srila Prabhupada in all his teachings he brings about, about the role of a saintly person in the human society. And hence in the Vedic conception, such a saintly person should have free access to move around in the human society and give this knowledge to whoever was ready to receive this.

#### impurity, desire, anger, lust, Vaikuntha, Krishna consciousness
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/LfFYYZdRfuk?t=0
**Verse References:** BG 7.27
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "People should learn Bhagavad Gita and accept the Supreme personality of Godhead Krishna as the Lord of everything, they should practice satisfying the senses of the Supreme Lord instead of trying to satisfy their own senses."
**Summary:** This segment introduces the Srimad Bhagavatam verse and Srila Prabhupada's purport, discussing the causes of falling into the material world and the path back to Vaikuntha through Krishna consciousness.

Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 3, Chapter 15, Text number 34. He is stated in Bhagavad Gita, 7th Chapter, Verse 27. It is stated that as long as a living entity is pure, he is in complete harmony with the desires of the Supreme Lord. But as soon as he becomes impure, he is in disharmony with the desires of the Lord. By contamination, he is forced to transfer to this material world, where the living entities have three enemies, namely, desire, anger, and lust. These three enemies force the living entities to continue material existence, and when one is free from them, he is eligible to enter the kingdom of God. One should not, therefore, be angry in the absence of an opportunity for sense gratification, and one should not be lusty to acquire more than necessary. In this verse, it is clearly stated that the two doormen should be sent into the material world, where criminals are allowed to reside. Since the basic principles of criminality are sense gratification, anger, and unnecessary lust, persons conducted by these three enemies of the living entity are never promoted to Vaikunthaloka. People should learn Bhagavad Gita and accept the Supreme Personality of Godhead Krishna as the Lord of everything. They should practice satisfying the senses of the Supreme Lord instead of trying to satisfy their own senses. Training in Krishna consciousness will help one be promoted to Vaikuntha. Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta purport.

**Summary:** The speaker introduces the verse and explains how the doormen of Vaikuntha reacted to being cursed by the Kumaras, understanding the gravity of offending devotees.

Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya. Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 3, Chapter 15, Text No. 35: teṣām itīritaṁ bhāvava dhārya-gōraṁ tam brahma-dandam anivāraṇaṁ astra-pūgaiḥ sadyo hareranu ca rāvuru bhibhyatāstāt pāda-gṛhāva patatārāṁ tāmatikātare nāṁ teṣām itīritaṁ bhāvava dhārya-gōraṁ tam brahma-dandam anivāraṇaṁ Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupāda: "When the doormen of Vaikunthaloka, who were certainly devotees of the Lord, found that they were going to be cursed by the brāhmaṇas, they at once became veiled. They were very much afraid and fell down at the feet of the brāhmaṇas in great anxiety, for a brāhmaṇa's curse cannot be counteracted by any kind of weapon. Although by chance the doormen committed a mistake by checking the brāhmaṇas from entering the gate of Vaikuntha, they were at once aware of the gravity of the curse. There are many kinds of offences, but the greatest offence is to offend a devotee of the Lord. Because the doormen were also devotees of the Lord, they were able to understand their mistake and were terrified when the four kumaras were ready to curse them." Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta purport.

When they heard that they were cursed to go to the material world, they understood what a grave thing, mistake, they have done: avadharya ghoram. tad brahmadandam anivaranam astrapugaihi. And they also realised, they became fearful about brahmadandam, the curse of a brahmana, which is anivaranam, nivaranam, anivaranam, which cannot be counteracted. astrapugaihi. One may think that I am very powerful, I have so many weapons, you may have any kind of weapons, but by these weapons you cannot, anivaranam, you cannot counteract brahmadandam. So realising this, avadharya ghoram, brahmadandam, anivaranam, astrapugaihi, anivaranam, what did they do? sadyaha, immediately, harer anucarao, those devotees, who are followers of hari, uruvibhyatas, full of fear, tadpada grahao apatatam, they fell at the feet of the sages, holding to their feet, apatatam, fell down, atikatha rena, with great anxiety in their heart. So when the doorman of Vaikunthaloka, who was certainly devotees of the Lord, harer anucarao, found that they were going to be cursed by the brahmanas, brahmadandam, they at once became very much afraid, uruvibhyatas, and fell down, apatatam, at the feet of the brahmanas, pada grahao apatatam, in great anxiety, atikatha rena, for a brahmana's curse, brahmadandam, cannot be counteracted, anivaranam, by any kind of weapon, astrapugai. So, we can see here, and Prabhupada has mentioned, because they were themselves devotees, they understood how grave ghoram it was to have offended the sages, and the sages becoming upset with them, and cursing them. So they became, they were, they became aware, they understood, avadharya ghoram, they understood what a grave mistake they have committed, and they became fearful, urubhibhyataha, and they fell at the feet of the brahmanas, atikatha rena, with great anxiety. And, so, what was the curse that the brahmanas, the sages had pronounced on them, that we saw in the previous verse, loka nitho vrajatam, go to the material world. So that was the curse about which they became very fearful, they became very anxious. So in other words, when they were told, go to the material world, that was considered to be a curse.

**Summary:** The speaker explains how to avoid mistakes in the material world by controlling our words, mind, and senses through constant devotion to the lotus feet of Hari, following the example of residents of the spiritual world.

And in the material world, we generally act through three things, according to Vedic understanding: by our words, we act. Right? By words we interact in this world, with our mind, and with our senses. And, sometimes, we have all experienced, sometimes we say something and things go wrong, in our relationship, or something happens. And we hurt somebody, and then after that we regret, oh my god, my words were not, I shouldn't have spoken like that. Or some emotions, or some thinking, through our mind also, we may sometimes make a mistake. But we act. And then, or through our senses, we act, knowledge acquiring and active senses. We act, and then we regret, oh I made a mistake, I shouldn't have done that. Right? These are the three ways by which we interact in this material world. And we can make mistakes in this. So, Lord Brahma gives in the Bhagavatam, a formula, which we will never go wrong with our words, we will never go wrong with our mind, we will never go wrong with our senses. And he says, if we follow this, we will be very safe. What is that? na bhārati meṅga mṛśopalakṣyate na bhārati meṅga mṛśopalakṣyate. Bhārati means untruth, or false, or a wrong path. Here the word Bhārati means one's words. na bhārati meṅga mṛśopalakṣyate. Lord Brahma is saying this to Narada Muni, "My dear, my words never fail. My words never go wrong. Utkanta means similar sense as... With great anxiety... With great fervor... I am constantly holding on to the lotus feet of Hari. If we hold on to the lotus feet of Hari, with great eagerness, with great zeal... Prabhupada translates that word Utkanta. Utkanta is connected to the word Vaikunta. Vaikunta means free from anxiety. Utkanta means with full... Not exactly anxiety... With full zeal... With a great deal of fervor I am holding on constantly to the lotus feet of Hari in my heart. But because of that... So this is the formula that Lord Brahma is giving, that how we can ensure in our life our words, our mind and our senses don't go astray. And that is by holding on firmly to the lotus feet of Hari all the time. Holding on to the lotus feet of Hari means always living by Harer Anucharaha. In the spiritual world, the residents are all Harer Anucharaha. They're always Anucharaha. They're constantly following the directions of Hari. That is the position of the pure living entity in the spiritual world. So by doing that, even in this material world, which is great calamity around us, we can be very safe. This is the instruction of the Bhagavatam.

It is said in the Brahma Samhita that devotees, being elevated in love of God, always see Shama Sundara, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, within their hearts. But when they are mature, the same God is visible before them face to face. For ordinary persons, the Lord is not visible. However, when one can understand the significance of his holy name, and one engages himself in the devotional service of the Lord, beginning with the tongue by chanting and tasting Prasad, then gradually the Lord reveals himself. Thus the devotee constantly sees the Lord within his heart, and in a more mature stage, one can see the same Lord directly, as we can see everything else.

### Three Dangerous Diversions from Bhakti-yoga | Sri Chanchalapathi Dasa
**Speaker:** HG Chanchalapathi Dasa

#### bhakti-yoga, karma, mukti, yogasiddhi, temptation, detachment
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/j8IUXnNznv8?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** analogy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "If you are able to somehow resist the temptation of these three exits, then you can head towards the supreme personality of Godhead."
**Summary:** The speaker uses the analogy of an expressway to illustrate how karma, mukti, and yogasiddhi can be diversions from the path of bhakti-yoga.

You're driving on the expressway, you're heading very quickly, but then you see exit, food court, and so you exit, and then you'll see so many different kinds of food all displayed there, and then you get absorbed and lost there, and then you missed the purpose that you were heading in the expressway. So, the shastras point out, when you are trying to advance in the mission of human life, you will encounter three exits. The first exit is called karma. The second exit is called mukti, and the third exit is called yogasiddhi. If you are not careful, you can take that exit, and you can be lost there completely, and forget coming back to the exit. So, you're driving on the expressway, and heading towards the goal that you set out. If you are able to somehow resist the temptation of these three exits, then you can head towards the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Because, if you want to associate with Krishna, you should be free from the temptations of karma, jnana, and yogasiddhi. That is a pure devotee, who only wants to serve Krishna.

#### Lord's enjoyment, free will, rasa, relationship
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/1sZaBCmjaYQ?t=167
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So that one personality becomes many for the purpose of relationship, for the purpose of enjoyment."
**Summary:** The Lord creates living entities to experience relationships and enjoyment, granting them free will to facilitate genuine rasa.

So, it's a battle for the demon, but it is a friendly fight, a playful fight for the Supreme Lord. Because the Supreme Lord does not have to fight with anybody. Right? He can only fight with one person. That is himself. There is nobody else to fight with. But being the Supreme person, being a personality with all the emotions in its most supreme, excellent position, he also has the tendency to fight. What does he do? Just like he has a tendency to exchange emotions, he has a tendency to enjoy rasa, raso vai saha. He is full of rasa, and he is the enjoyer of all the rasas. So, what does he do? He has to create Radharani. He has to create all the sakis. He has to create all the devotees. He has to create all the living entities. So that one personality becomes many for the purpose of relationship, for the purpose of enjoyment. But if there has been enjoyment, and if there has been a relationship, then one thing he has to give up. He has to give up one thing. That is free will. If it doesn't give free will, if he is controlling the living entities he has created, if he is controlling all the people he has created, then it becomes... There is no rasa in that. Rasa comes when there is unexpected situations. You don't expect something. Suddenly something comes up. Then the enjoyment is more. If you already know what to expect, then there is no enjoyment there. When you receive something unexpectedly, then the rasa, the taste is more. You suddenly go somewhere you don't expect, suddenly get nice prasadam. Even though it is not tasty, you feel it is very tasty. You are very hungry. You didn't expect. So, to give that, rasa of the unknown, the Lord gives up the free will. So the living entities have only one thing. That is his free will. Everything else is Lord. He is also part of the Lord. Part and parcel of the Lord. There is no difference between the living entity and the Lord, except for the quantum. Both are spirit. Quantity wise maybe. So he gives that free will. So that is the free will which is used by the living entities. And using that free will, the Lord makes the living entity give him pleasure. The living entities are part and parcel of the Lord. So just like the part and parcel is used by the whole, the Supreme Lord uses the living entities by making the living entities act the way he wants.

#### material world, friendly fight, Lord's love
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/1sZaBCmjaYQ?t=359
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** analogy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "All the bad words you throw upon the Lord is received as a loving flower."
**Summary:** The material world is a place where living entities try to imitate the Lord, but the Lord responds with love, even to negative actions.

But many of the living entities are not qualified. All of them, like us, find place in this material world. So that is how the Supreme Lord exchanges relationships. So for him here, it is a friendly fight. Just like a father would fight. The gloves also father has given to the son. Right? Everything that the son has to fight the father. Suppose the father is a king. He wants to fight with the son. He gives a sword to the son. All the elements to fight is given by the father. And the father says, now you fight. Right? Sometimes the father shows he is also defeated. Because the father feels pleasure in the success of the son. Similarly, the Lord also feels pleasure in the success of the living entities. Only one thing is not possible when the living entities start imitating and acting like the Lord. That is not possible. Because there is only one Lord. So when Hiranyakasya, Hiranyakashipu, all the living entities try to act like the Lord, then, still the Lord is loving. The Lord doesn't say, you are dismissed. You are banned. If he bans, where will the living entity go? So he himself has to create the living entity's place. So he creates a material world. And he says, all of you go there and try to become like me. So we have Hiranyakasya and Hiranyakashipu here. Trying to fight the Lord. But what is the use of fighting the Lord? All the bad words you throw upon the Lord is received as a loving flower. All the beating that Hiranyakasya does to the Lord is also received to him as pleasure. So you cannot overcome that. You cannot overcome the Lord in any way. That's not possible. The living entity can get overcome by the Lord's love. So that is the interaction between the Lord and the living entities.

Why did he take the form of a wild boar? Because earth is lost. It has been sniffed. It has been smelled and found out. And nobody is as expert as smelling like wild boar. You cannot keep anything away from a wild boar. It will sniff and find out. It is a very lowly animal, but very expert. His sense of smelling is so strong. Right? So the point here is, the Lord doesn't mind taking this kind of form also for the pleasure of His pleasure and the pleasure of the devotees.
