#### dodging death, transcendentalism, detachment
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/1sZaBCmjaYQ?t=628
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So the process of dodging death, that is the goal of life."
**Summary:** The speaker explains that the Lord dodges the maze of Hiranyaksha like a transcendentalist dodges death, which is achieved by disconnecting from the material world and identifying as spirit soul.

So that is the situation here. But here, Sukte Goswami very clearly explains, the Lord is dodging the maze of hidden action. So if you look at it, He is dancing, sidestepping, maze fight. Duryodhana, Bhima, all these people are great maze fighters. So we look at the maze fighters, if you look at any fighter, you have to see, you have to block others beating, you have to avoid others beating, you have to give a punch. So it is a real fighting. There is a big war going on there. So the Lord is dodging the maze, maze blows of hidden action, just like a transcendentalist would dodge death. So He gives that comparison. So the transcendentalists are expert in dodging death. How does that happen? Well, in the sense, dodging death means you avoid the influence of the material world, because death is part of this material world. Soul doesn't die. So when soul doesn't die, who is dying here? Transcendentalist doesn't die. He is soul. How can soul die? It is the body which is dying. Body which is a part of the material world, which is dying. Body which is the product of the influence of the three modes of material nature, which is dying. And He was never that body. So transcendentalists never die. It is the living entities who think that He is a body, which has an end, think that there is death. For a spiritualist, there is no death. So the Lord is dodging this maze, just like a Vaishnava, a Brahmana, a qualified spiritualist who avoids death. Well, not only the Vaishnavas, even a Mayavadi tries to dodge death. Any transcendentalist, whether he is a Mayavadi, he is a yogi, he is a Brahmana, he is a Vaishnava, they all dodge death. But dodging death is possible only when you disconnect with the material world. Until that disconnect comes, because you think, I am the body. As long as we think that we are the body, and the body ends, we cannot dodge.

So the quality of a transcendentalist is this, he is free from this fear, he is free from this anxiety, he is free from this dissatisfied situation of material things that I have only this much. #### material world, upside-down tree, three modes
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/1sZaBCmjaYQ?t=1057
**Verse References:** BG 15.1
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "This world is nothing but an upside down of a good world."
**Summary:** Drawing from the 15th chapter of Gita, the speaker describes the material world as an upside-down tree, nourished by the three modes of material nature, and sustained by the actions of living entities.

So that is why Krishna as in 15th chapter he says, a person who understands this material world, he understands very clearly what is happening in this world. Hence he says, what is this world? In 15th chapter of Gita, most important chapter, where Krishna says, urdhamulam adasyakam. You want to know what this world is? This world is nothing but an upside down of a good world. This is a perverted reflection of the right world. This is a wrong house. This is an upside down house. You belong to a house which is totally different. But I can try to explain to you, this world is an upside down world. And this is like a tree which is standing on a reservoir. The reflection is seen on the reservoir. The roots are up. The branches are down. The leaves are down. The leaves are the Vedas. The twigs are the fruits of the senses, objects of the senses. Sense activities. And this tree also has new roots coming. This tree also has new shoots coming. And this tree is fed by the three modes of material nature, sattva guna, raja guna, tamma guna. It is like growing up a tree using manure. What is the manure for this tree? Urea for this tree is sattva guna, raja guna, tamma guna. These three gunas are the nutrients by which the tree is growing. And what is the fruit of the tree? The new twigs. And all this is resting in the action of the living entities. If the living entity is acting in this material world, using these three gunas, sattva guna, raja guna, tamma guna, which are the nutrients, naturally new roots will come. Just like in a banyan tree, new roots come. Very thin roots come. When they are very small, easy to pick and throw. But as they touch the ground, and they also start sucking the three gunas, the nutrients, they also grow strong. So by the action of the living entities, by the influence of three modes of material nature, the nutrients are going to this tree called samsara. And this tree called samsara is growing and growing and growing. And it comes to a point where you cannot cut it anymore easily. The more nutrient is taken, the tree becomes very strong. You cannot cut it. A tree which is very small, you can easily take it away. But allow it to grow. Allow the extra roots to come. Who is feeding it? Nobody external is coming and feeding it. We ourselves are feeding it by our action. What kind of action? The actions which are influenced by either sattva guna, raja guna, tamma guna or a combination of these. So actions in this material world,

is a cause of bondage. And Lord says, he who knows this tree, he can dodge death. He can be free from the influence of this tree. Don't try to understand this tree. When he uses his free will in another way, he gets liberated. So that one item what the Lord has given, that is a free will, action means free will. You are free to act whichever you want. #### endeavor, karma, Lord's sanction, dodging death
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/1sZaBCmjaYQ?t=1542
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "This world is made so real, that one has to endeavor."
**Summary:** The material world is a place of endeavor, limited by karma and time, but ultimately controlled by the Lord's sanction, and dodging death means dodging these influences.

This world is made so real by the Lord that we have to struggle. Three things are there in this world. One is our endeavor. Every time we endeavor for something to success, achieve something. Free from hatred, free from happiness, free from unhappiness, or achieve happiness. These are two things we do. Endeavor is always there. But we are limited. We are not free to endeavor. Not that you do anything, you will get the result. You are limited by time. Limited by our past. Limited by our own karma. Right? And then, even if you have good karma, sometimes you may not get it. Why? Large interference is there. So this world is made so real, that one has to endeavor. While endeavoring, one is limited by one's past. And even if it is limited by the past, if the Lord's sanction is there, you get it. So by seeing this world, one understands there is something different. Somebody is controlling this world. I am not free. If I was free, I should work hard and I should get the result. But you see people working hard, opposite result. Viparyaya, you get the opposite. You try for something, but you get the exact opposite. Or sometimes people don't work at all, he is getting everything automatically. So big debate in Shastra is, what is the reason for result in this world? Is it endeavor? Is it karma? Or the Lord? Of course, it is a combination of all these three. So Krishna has created this world where he makes the living entities endeavor. Work hard, work hard, work hard. Again action. Again free will. The same free will what he has given to the living entities, he is making the living entities work hard. Endeavor, endeavor, endeavor. But, you have come and gone many times here. So many pending accounts are there. It depends upon that. Even great athletes work hard day and night they work. On the day of the play, no result. So they say, I didn't have a good day. So having good day is important or struggling for so many years is important. Why struggle at all? Some people don't struggle at all. You have a good day by your past karma. So the world is made so real by the Lord, by a combination of all these things. And the living entities who understand this, he knows, I am limited by all these things. And finally, I am limited by death. So how do you dodge death? Say a person dodging death means he dodges all these influences of karma, influences of time, influences of the three modes. Then he can dodge.

**Summary:** The purpose of the world is to achieve liberation, and devotees should avoid growing roots in material attachments, using their free will to dodge death through practical action.

That is the purpose of the world. You may not use it for that purpose. You may use it for your own sense gratification. Then you get caught up in that. Many times people get caught up in this world of materialism and get frustrated. When they get frustrated, they say the world is not real. When they are enjoying, they don't say the world is not real. But the devotee may be utilizing everything in this material world. He may enjoy also. Ambarish Maharaj, Dhruva Maharaj, all these people, they enjoy the material world, according to their karma. But, they were not growing roots. By the action of Dhruva Maharaj, even though he was a king and ruling, he didn't grow roots. The problem is growing roots. Similarly, in our preaching movement, when we preach and engage in Krishna consciousness, we should see that roots are not grown. We don't get stuck with a particular service. We don't get stuck with a particular situation. We don't get stuck with a particular position. We don't get stuck with a particular concept. Everything is the roots of, if the roots are built here, then there is no difference between the activity inside and activity outside. Because action is the only way to get liberation. #### divine intervention, devotion, miracle
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/mhmDSyTj43k?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Bhirachandra Prabhu then took the stone back to Kardaha by floating it into the Ganges, as if it was too heavy to board onto a boat."
**Summary:** This segment narrates the story of how Bhirachandra Prabhu obtained the Shaligram Shila from the Nawab's palace in Murshidabad, highlighting the miraculous transformation of food into flowers and the floating of the stone on the Ganges.

It is stated in Prema Vilasa that Sri Bhirachandra Prabhu, after having received appropriate instructions from his father, Nithyananda Prabhu, to install Sri Shamasundraji in Kardaha, had set out to obtain the Shaligram Shila from the Nawab's palace in Murshidabad, from which the deity needed to be carved. Sri Bhirachandra Prabhu's reputation preceded him, and the Nawab greeted him with full honor on his arrival. However, the Nawab had evil intentions. Sri Bhirachandra's vow of feeding him meat. Hence, the Nawab thought that feeding meat to this great Vaishnava would end up derailing him from his religious path and shall thereby spoil his reputation. However, when Nawab attempted to serve him the non-veg dishes, the food automatically got transformed into roses and jasmine. The Nawab ordered his chief to bring new items. But again, the potency of Sri Bhirachandra, the food got transformed into flowers. The Nawab got frustrated in his attempts and finally came to realize that Sri Bhirachandra Prabhu was a great devotee and no ordinary personality. Feeling remorseful and guilty, the Nawab fell at his lotus feet and begged him for forgiveness. Bhirachandra Prabhu, feeling merciful, forgave him. Bhirachandra Prabhu then informed the Nawab, "I saw you eating the food. I saw a huge stone above your front gate. I would be happy to have it so that I can carve a nice deity out of it." The Nawab was very happy to give his consent. Bhirachandra Prabhu then took the stone back to Kardaha by floating it into the Ganges, as if it was too heavy to board onto a boat. To the surprise of all, the Shaligramma stone floated down the river and ultimately reached the banks of Kardaha, where it was carefully recovered.

#### deity installation, divine manifestation, worship
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/mhmDSyTj43k?t=148
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The third deity which manifested from the Shaligramma Silla was an exact match."
**Summary:** This segment describes the process of carving the deity of Lord Shamsundara from the Shaligram Shila, the rejection of the first two deities, and the grand installation festival performed by Achyutananda.

While meditating at Kunjavatika, Sri Bhirachandra had received the beautiful darshana of Sri Shamsundaraji in his heart. In his trance, he received orders from his father, Nithyananda Prabhu, to fetch the Shaligramma Silla from the Nawab's place and subsequently install Shamsundaraji here in Kardaha. This concerned Shaligramma Silla had a long history. This was the same stone on which Kamsa, the wicked maternal uncle of Sri Krishna, had murdered the six children of Devaki over 5000 years ago. Somehow the stone had landed up in the custody of the Nawab. As Bhirachandra Prabhu entered the Nawab's palace, he noticed that the stone was perspiring and understood that it was the same Shaligramma Silla that he had come looking for. Sri Bhirachandra then engaged a sculptor who fulfilled his earnest desire by carving the captivating deity of Lord Shamsundara from this Shaligramma Silla. The first two deities that were sculpted didn't match the exact form of Shri Shamsundaraji that Bhirachandra had witnessed in his meditation. Hence, he sent these first two deities to Shirampur and Saiban, where they are worshipped today as Shri Radha Vallabhji and Shri Radha Nandudulalji respectively. The third deity which manifested from the Shaligramma Silla was an exact match, and Shri Bhirachandra then proceeded to install and worship it. Indeed, the people of Kardaha forgot their distress when they saw this most attractive deity. Bhirachandra Prabhu arranged a grand festival to install the deity with great pomp and show, and so, inviting many devotees and feeding all of them sumptuously, the most merciful Achyutananda, the son of Advaitacharya, performed the abhisheka of Shri Radha Shamsundaraji.

#### Haridasa Thakura, association, chanting, holy name
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/pzMGkDdfoBE?t=628
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "If one actually chants the holy name without offences, his ecstatic love for the lotus feet of Lord Krishna is awakened."
**Summary:** The speaker narrates another pastime of Haridas Thakur, where he is invited to a gathering and discusses the glories of the holy name, emphasizing that the true result of chanting is ecstatic love for Krishna.

There is one more pastime in Chaitanya Charitamrita. Haridas Thakur walked until he came to the village of Chandapura, later known as Krishnapura, where he stayed at Balaram Acharya's house. Balaram Acharya was the family priest of Hiranya and Govardhana Majumda. Due to receiving his favour, Balaram Acharya was very attached to Haridas Thakur, and thus, he provided all his needs with great care and attention. Haridas Thakur was given a cottage in a secluded place and he came daily to Balaram Acharya's house to accept prasad. At that time, Raghunath Das was a schoolboy and he used to come and see Haridas Thakur every day. Naturally, Haridas Thakur was very merciful towards him, and as a result, Raghunath Das later on attained to his love. Haridas Thakur was immediately sheltered at the lotus feet of Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. Regular discourses were held at the residence of Hiranya and Govardhana. One day, Balaram Acharya very humbly invited Haridas Thakur to come there. Upon seeing Haridas Thakur arrive, the two Majumdaras immediately stood up and then fell at his lotus feet to offer obeisances. There were many learned scholars, brahmanas and respectable gentlemen in that assembly, and Hiranya and Govardhana were also greatly learned. As the two brothers very respectfully offered Haridas Thakur a sitting place, everyone began to speak about his exalted qualities as if they each possessed five mouths. Hiranya and Govardhana were very pleased to hear this talk. When it was mentioned how Haridas Thakur chanted 300,000 holy names daily, the learned scholars began to discuss the glories of the holy name of the Lord. Some of them said, by chanting the holy name of the Lord, one is freed from all reactions to sinful activities. Others said, simply by chanting the holy name of the Lord, one becomes liberated from material bondage. Haridas Thakur protested. These two benedictions are not the true result of chanting the holy name of the Lord. If one actually chants the holy name without offences, his ecstatic love for the lotus feet of Lord Krishna is awakened.

#### chanting, holy name, liberation, devotion, Srimad Bhagavatam
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/pzMGkDdfoBE?t=786
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Liberation is thus the insignificant result derived from a mere glimpse of awakening of offenceless chanting."
**Summary:** Haridas Thakur explains the meaning of a verse from Srimad Bhagavatam, emphasizing that liberation is a byproduct of chanting the holy name without offenses, and that pure devotees desire ecstatic love for Krishna, not liberation.

In Srimad Bhagavatam, it is said, when a person is actually advanced and takes pleasure in chanting the holy name of the Lord, who is very dear to him, he becomes agitated, and thus sometimes laughs, sometimes cries, and sometimes chants loudly and dances without caring for outsiders. Liberation and the destruction of sinful reactions are two concomitant byproducts of chanting the holy name of the Lord. As the rising sun immediately dissipates all the world's darkness, so the holy name of the Lord, even if chanted only once without offences, dispels all of one's sinful reactions. Haridas Thakur questioned, O learned scholars, please explain the meaning of this verse. However, the audience responded, it would be better if you explain the meaning of this important verse. Haridas Thakur said, even before the sun rises in the morning, it dissipates the darkness of night with its dawning light, and thus all fear of thieves and ghosts immediately vanishes. Then, when the sun actually becomes visible, everything is clearly manifest and people begin performing their morning religious activities and other duties. Similarly, the first glimpse of offenceless chanting of the Lord's holy name immediately dissipates all reactions to sinful life. Then, when one is actually on the platform of offenceless chanting, there awakens a static loving devotional service to the lotus feet of Krishna. Liberation is thus the insignificant result derived from a mere glimpse of awakening of offenceless chanting. An example of such an effect of Nama Bhasa is seen in the life of Ajamila. Liberation, which is unacceptable to a pure devotee, is very easily offered by Lord Krishna.

#### Haridasa Thakura, criticism, chanting, liberation, offense
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/pzMGkDdfoBE?t=907
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "One cannot understand the glories of the holy name of the Lord simply by mundane logic and argument."
**Summary:** The story continues with Gopal Chakravarti criticizing Haridas Thakur's statements about liberation through chanting, leading to a challenge and eventual dismissal from service.

There was a person named Gopal Chakravarti staying at Hiranya and Govardhana's house. He was the chief tax collector, and it was his duty to collect 12 lakh coins and deposit them in the emperor's treasury. This caste brahmana had very handsome bodily features, and he was very learned and youthful. However, he could not tolerate hearing the statement that one can achieve liberation by glimpsing the awakening of pure chanting of the Lord's holy name. Becoming very angry, Gopal Chakravarti began criticizing Haridas Thakur as follows. O learned scholars, just hear the conclusion of this emotional devotee. After many millions of births, when one becomes complete in transcendental knowledge, one may still not attain liberation. Yet, this man says that it can be obtained simply by awakening a glimpse of the holy name of the Lord. Haridas Thakur replied, Why are you doubtful? Shastra clearly states that one can attain liberation simply by a slight glimpse of offenseless chanting. For the devotee who enjoys the transcendental bliss of devotional service, liberation is most insignificant, like the water containing within the hoof print of a calf. Gopal Chakravarti said, If one is not liberated by such namabasa chanting, then I shall certainly cut off your nose. Haridas Thakur accepted this challenge by saying, If by namabasa liberation is not available, then I shall certainly cut off my own nose. After hearing Gopal Chakravarti's challenge, everyone gathered there became very agitated, and while getting up from their seats, they made a tumultuous noise. Hiranya and Govardhana immediately went and began chastising Gopal Chakravarti, and Balram Acharya told him, You are a foolish logician. What do you know about the devotional service of the Lord? Since you have insulted Haridas Thakur, you have put yourself in a very dangerous position and so you should not expect anything auspicious. The two Majumdaras immediately dismissed Gopal Chakravarti from their service. Then, as Haridas Thakur got up to leave, they went along with the other members of the assembly and fell at his lotus feet. While smiling, Haridas Thakur spoke to them as follows in a very sweet voice, None of you are at fault. Indeed, even this ignorant so-called brahmana is not to be blamed, for he is accustomed to dry speculation and logic. One cannot understand the glories of the holy name of the Lord simply by mundane logic and argument.

The place, in fact, is very near to the international border post between India and Bangladesh. Let me offer my respectful obeisances unto Haridas Thakura and his master Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, who danced with the body of Haridas Thakur on his lap. Choosing a solitary forest for his stay over here at Benapol, Haridas Thakur set up a cottage and established his bhajana kutira. He planted tulasi, and in front of tulasi devi, he used to chant 300,000 holy names of Lord Krishna daily. He chanted through the day and night. In order to sustain his body, he used to beg for food from a brahmana who lived nearby.

She flattered Haridas Chakur, saying how beautiful he looked and how desperate she was to enjoy him. Sri Hrishikananda Prabhu was born in 1590 in the village of Rayani, in the Medinipura district. His father's name was Raja Achuthananda, a rich zamindar, and his mother, Bhavani Devi. Medinapur district used to be part of Orissa kingdom. Hrishikananda was also known by the name Hrishikamurari. Hrishikamurari meets Shamananda Prabhu. One day, Hrishikamurari was meditating in a solitary place. He was anxious to find a spiritual master who could give him spiritual direction. He had entered into a very deep meditation when he heard a disembodied voice say, "Murari, you need not be anxious any longer. Your guru is Shamananda Prabhu and you will meet him here very shortly. Take shelter of him and your life will be successful." Upon hearing this divine message, Murari began chanting the name of Shamananda on his beads with joyful enthusiasm. He spent the entire night crying out of his desire to meet his guru. At dawn, Hrishikamurari was on the lookout for his guru when he saw the tall figure of Shamananda approaching him, as effulgent as the sun, surrounded by his disciples. He started dancing and chanting the name of Lord Nityananda. Having waited anxiously for so long to encounter his guru, Hrishikamurari immediately fell at his feet. Shamananda affectionately lifted him up and embraced him and later initiated him with the Radha Krishna mantra.

#### Kamalaksha's birth, Holy rivers, Paana Tirtha, Jadukatha river
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/EAQRc5pezvo?t=224
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Shri Advaita assured his mother and vowed to summon all the holy rivers to Lauda, so that she does not have to travel to bathe in the Ganges."
**Summary:** This segment describes Advaita Acharya's birth name Kamalaksha, his mother's dream, his promise to bring the holy rivers to Lauda, and the creation of Paana Tirtha and Jadukatha river.

Waves of divine ecstasy flooded the people of Navahadevi. On the advice of learned astrologers, Shri Kubera Pandita and Navahadevi named their son Kamalaksha. Navahadevi once desired to take a dip in the holy Ganges. She saw a dream one night in which her son Kamalaksha revealed himself as four-handed Lord Vishnu. Beholding the Supreme Lord before her, she immediately offered her prayers in glorification. Shri Advaita assured his mother and vowed to summon all the holy rivers to Lauda, so that she does not have to travel to bathe in the Ganges. Upon waking up, Navahadevi seemed quite confused. Although she was initially reluctant to disclose her dream, Navahadevi finally revealed it to her son on his insistence. A seven-year-old Advaita then shone again and he would bring all the holy Tirthas to Lauda to fulfill the desires of his dear mother. Thereafter, during the night, Shri Advaita entered into a deep meditation and summoned the holy rivers. He then ordered them to reside at Lauda during the Madhu Krishna Trayodashi Tithi so that his mother can bathe in them. Accordingly, Ganga, Jamuna, Narmada, Kaveri, Saraswati, Udavari, etc. reached and gathered near the mountains of Lauda. The next morning, Advaita Acharya took his mother so that she could experience the wonder with her own eyes. As soon as Advaita chanted the names of the Supreme Lord and blew upon his conch shell, the holy rivers started pouring down from the mountains. Some of them were reddish, some were bluish, some were white, while some were yellow. Shri Kamalaksha introduced each of the rivers to his mother. This exalted dham came to be subsequently known as Paana Tirtha as it was Advaita Acharya's vow, Paana in Bengali means vow, that had caused the holy river to descend to this place. This newly created water body came to be known as Jadukatha river as it was shaped by Advaita's magic.

Shri Advaita had also come to attend the occasion along with Kubera Pandita. When the king noticed that Shri Advaita did not pay obeisances unto the deity of Goddess Kali, he requested him to do the same. Shri Advaita however refused, reasoning that any person who worships other demigods or demigoddesses instead of worshipping the Supreme Lord Shri Krishna is cast into bewilderment and material misery. Hearing his son's statement, Shri Kubera Pandita countered Advaita and urged him to pay his obeisances unto Maa Kali to not disrespect her. Shri Advaita consented to fulfill his father's desire, but as soon as Advaita Acharya entered the temple and paid his prostrated obeisances, the deity of Kali broke into pieces. The king came to tears witnessing the broken deity. Goddess Kali could not tolerate receiving obeisances from Shri Advaita, the combined incarnation of Mahavishnu and Sadashiva, her most worshipable lord. Shri Advaita did not wish to reveal his divine identity to anyone just yet. Hence, after this pastime, he moved over to Shantipur where he occupied himself with studying devotional scriptures and propagating the glories of Shri Krishna.

#### Mahaprabhu's prema for Narottama, Padmavati river, Dream and receiving Prema

**Verse References:** —

**Summary:** This segment describes Mahaprabhu's prema (love) for Narottama, his request to the Padmavati river to safeguard it, and Narottama's eventual reception of this prema after bathing in the river.

According to Prema Vilasa, When Mahaprabhu passed through Kanena Shala, he was dancing ecstatically in Kirtan. He began to call out the name Narottama, Narottama. When Nithyananda asked him why he was calling out this name, Mahaprabhu answered, There will be one exalted devotee by the name Narottama, will soon be born here. Mahaprabhu then went on to the Padmavati river on the place known as Kutuppur, where he bathed and sang and danced in ecstasy. He then called out to the river, O Padmavati, take my love and keep it here. When Narottama comes and bathes here, give it to him. The Padmavati inquired, How will I recognize him? Mahaprabhu answered, You will know it is Narottama, for when he enters your water, you will overflow. The place where Mahaprabhu placed Prema for Narottama's sake, was later given the name Premtali. When Narottama was twelve years old, he had a dream in which Nithyananda Prabhu told him to bathe in the Padmavati and take the Prema which had been stored there for him. He went the next day to the Padma and as soon as he put his foot in the water, the river started to overflow. The Padmavati then remembered Mahaprabhu's words and gave Narottama the Prema which she had been safeguarding for him.

**Summary:** This segment recounts Narottama Das Thakur's journey to Vrindavan, his desire to inaugurate six deities, and the grand festival he organized at Keturi for this purpose, including the arrangements and the prominent Vaishnava attendees.

After this, Narottama leaves home and goes to Vrindavan. Narottama Das Thakur wished to inaugurate his six deities on the auspicious occasion of Gaurapurnima at his hometown in Keturi. He decided to arrange a grand festival at Keturi and celebrate this occasion with great pomp and show. Narottama Das Thakur's brother, Sri Santosh Dutta, who was also a devout Vaishnava, had inherited the kingdom from his father, Sri Krishnananda. Accordingly, as per the instructions of his brother, Santosh began making all the necessary arrangements. He ordered the construction of temples at Keturi, where these six deities would subsequently be installed. Sri Narottama Das Thakur personally invited Srimati Janavamata, Sri Srinivasa Acharya, Ramachandra Kaviraj, and several other deities. Narottama Das Thakur was the first stalwart Vaishnavas to attend the festival at Keturi. During this grand festival that took place 500 years ago, Gaudiya Vaishnavas from all over India had come to participate. Sri Shamananda Pandita from Narasimha Pura, Srimati Janava Devi from Kardaha, Sri Parameshwari Das Thakura, Srinivasa Acharya along with his disciples, Krishna Das Sarkhel, Madhavacharya, Raghupati Vaidya, Manikandan Ramdas, Murari Chaitanya, Jnana Das, Mahi Das, Sri Shankara, Kamalakara, all these people. King Santoshadatta arranged for innumerable boats to transport devotees to the other side of river Padma. Numerous bullock carts and palanquins were arranged to ensure that the devotees faced no problems reaching Keturi. The whole atmosphere was surcharged with a mood of love and surrenderance. Narasimha Das Thakur, Santoshadatta and Srinivasa Acharya personally welcomed the guests with chandana and garland. Rooms and servants were arranged for each of the guests. The dust of the feet of such exalted Vaishnavas transformed Keturi into an exalted place of pilgrimage. Loud reverberations of Harinam Sankirtan were heard and the sound of hridanga and kartas enraptured the sky. Not only the temple but each and every house of the town was explicitly decorated with banana leaves, auspicious pots, etc. Huge quantity of ghee, milk, vegetables and puja paraphernalia were arranged. Sri Gauranga, Vallabhikanta, Brajamohan, Shri Krishna, Shri Radhakanta, Shri Radharamana.

So we saw the house where they were all staying after lunch this afternoon. According to hearsay, after his marriage, Lord Nithyananda had requested the local Zavindar here in Kardaha to kindly allot him a piece of land where he and his family could reside. The Zavindar, being unaware of Lord Nithyananda's divinity, rebuked him for abandoning his sanyasa and accepting a wife later on. The Zavindar, at the time of conversation, was fishing along with his friends. He sarcastically replied to Nithyananda that if he really needed a piece of land to stay, then he would have to create it out of water. Saying this, the zamindar threw a piece of burning straw into the Ganges in order to mark the place on water where the zamindar decided Lord Nithyananda should set up his residence, making fun of Lord Nithyananda Prabhu in front of his friends. Nithyananda Prabhu, who always remained very humble and without any anger, did not mind the zamindar's harsh words and assured the zamindar that whatever he had wished, though sarcastically, would surely come to pass. What happened next stunned all present. A huge mass of land suddenly appeared from the water exactly at the place where the burning piece of straw had hit it. Then this newly created island then got connected with the mainland. This place subsequently came to be known as Kardaha. Kar means straw in Bengali.

**Summary:** Krishna, as Paramatma, monitors souls and guides those ready to give up material life to a Guru, who then trains them to realize Krishna.

You see, who comes into contact, who doesn't come into contact, that is arranged by Krishna, who is seated in the heart of the devotee. Every soul is germinating in this material world. Krishna is in your heart. Is this devotee still not fed up with this world? Does he want to come to me or not? Is he questioning what is life? All that Krishna is monitoring in the heart, Paramatma. So therefore, Paramatma, not destiny, Paramatma who knows your spiritual past, who knows your spiritual inclination, who knows how much you are fed up with this world, who knows whether this person is seeking for the truth beyond this illusion, whether this Atma is seeking for purpose of life, all that somebody is monitoring. Who is that? Paramatma. Paramatma takes you to Prabhupada. What is the use of Paramatma bringing you to Prabhupada? Somebody who is not ready to give up his material life and who is completely absorbed in illusion. When Prabhupada went to America, even though they were all very materialistic, these foreigners, they all had searched for truth. What is life? They all had this question. So right there, immediately Prabhupada planted the answers. Yes. So it is not that Prabhupada went to America and he touched everybody and only few became devotees. No. He didn't touch many. Millions of Americans are there. They don't even know who Prabhupada is. Right? So Krishna arranged some souls who are ready. It is said that Krishna brings one to Guru and Guru takes you to Krishna. Paramatma brings you to Guru and Guru takes you and trains you and makes you realize the Supreme Lord Krishna. That Krishna's one aspect is Paramatma. Vande krishnam jagat gurum vise. Who is that? It is the Supersoul. So Supersoul brings you to Guru, Guru brings you to Krishna. Why? Because you have to learn how to become a devotee. Somebody who is a devotee is the best person to teach you how to become a devotee, not God. God is not a devotee. God is receiver of devotee service. So God leaves that duty to the devotee.

#### oral reception, spiritual master, service, Krishna consciousness
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/b4SP84ASur8?t=117
**Verse References:** BG 2.47
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Bhagavad Gita makes it clear that one can attain the highest perfection of spiritual life simply by offering service according to his ability, just as Arjuna served Krishna by his ability in the military art."
**Summary:** This segment emphasizes receiving transcendental messages through oral reception from a spiritual master, who guides individuals to perform duties in Krishna Consciousness according to their abilities, referencing Arjuna's service as a military man.

It is the function of a saintly person to invoke Krishna Consciousness in every forgetful common man. Manu said that since he was advised and instructed by Kardamma Muni, he was very much favoured. He considered himself lucky to receive the message by oral reception. It is especially mentioned here that one should be very inquisitive to hear with open ears from the authorized source of the bona fide spiritual master. How is one to receive? One should receive the transcendental message by oral reception. The word, Karnarandhraja, means through the holes of the ears. The favour of the spiritual master is not received through any other part of the body but the ears. This does not mean, however, that the spiritual master gives a particular type of mantra through the ears in exchange for some dollars and if the man meditates on that, he achieves perfection and becomes God within six months. Such reception through the ears is bogus. The real fact is that the bona fide spiritual master knows the nature of a particular man and what sort of duties he can perform in Krishna Consciousness and he instructs him in that way. He instructs him through the ear not privately but publicly, you are fit for such and such work in Krishna Consciousness, you can act in this way. One person is advised to act in Krishna Consciousness by working in the deity's room. Another is advised to act in Krishna Consciousness by performing editorial work. Another is advised to do preaching work. And another is advised to carry out Krishna Consciousness in the cooking department. There are different departments of activity in Krishna Consciousness and a spiritual master, knowing the particular ability of a particular man, trains him in such a way that by his tendency to act, he becomes perfect. Bhagavad Gita makes it clear that one can attain the highest perfection of spiritual life simply by offering service according to his ability, just as Arjuna served Krishna by his ability in the military art.

Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, 10-3, Chapter 22, Entitled The Marriage of Kardamamuni and Devahuti, Verse No. 10: YADATU BHAVATASILA SHRUTA RUPA VAYO DUNAN ASHRANON NARADHA DESHA TVAYAYA SITRITANISHAYA. Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada: "The moment she heard from the sage Narada of your noble character, learning, beautiful appearance, youth and other virtues, she fixed her mind upon you." Purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada: "The girl Devahuti did not personally see Kardamamuni, nor did she personally experience his character or qualities, since there was no social intercourse by which she could gain such understanding. But she heard about Tridamamuni from the authority of Narada Muni. Hearing from an authority is a better experience than gaining personal understanding. She heard from Narada Muni that Tridamamuni was just fit to be her husband, therefore she became fixed in her heart that she would marry him, and she expressed her desire to her father who therefore brought her before him." Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta Parvat. Devahuti, the daughter of Swayambhuva Manu, came to fix her mind upon desiring Kardamamuni, is being explained by Manu, and it is specifically explained in the purport by Prabhupada that she knew about Kardamamuni only by hearing from Narada Muni. And by hearing from Narada Muni about Kardamamuni, she got a better experience than even gaining personal understanding. #### guru-disciple relationship, humility, prayer
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/YgfS_Iid9sM?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Swayambhuva Manu was concerned about getting his daughter married and obviously he had in his mind Karadvama Muni."
**Summary:** HG Madhu Pandit Dasa begins by reciting and translating a verse from Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on Swayambhuva Manu's humble approach to Karadvama Muni, highlighting the importance of respect and grace in the guru-disciple relationship.

om namo bhagavate vasudevaya om namo bhagavate vasudevaya Madbhagavatam, Canto 3, Chapter 22, Text 8 sabhavandh trasneha pariklishthatmano mama srotam arhasi dhinasya shravitam kripaya mune Translation in purport by S. D. V. Bhai Charanarvinda Bhaktivedanta Swamishila Prabhupada Translation O great sage, graciously be pleased to listen to the prayer of my humble self, for my mind is troubled by affection from my daughter. Purport by Srila Prabhupada: When a disciple is perfectly in consonance with the spiritual master, having received his message and executed it perfectly and sincerely, he has a right to ask a particular favour from the spiritual master. Generally, a pure devotee of the Lord or a pure disciple of a bona fide spiritual master does not ask any favour either from the Lord or the spiritual master. But even if there is a need to ask a favour from the spiritual master, one cannot ask that favour without satisfying him fully. Swayambhuva Manu wanted to disclose his mind regarding the function he wanted to execute due to affection for his daughter. Thus ends the bhaktivedanta purport. Swayambhuva Manu is seeking the attention of Karadvama Muni to consider his prayer with regard to something that is disturbing his mind or troubled by the affection for my daughter.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/YgfS_Iid9sM?t=660
**Verse References:** —

**Summary:** The speaker reads Srila Prabhupada's purport, emphasizing the importance of receiving instructions from a bona fide spiritual master and executing them according to one's capacity in Krishna Consciousness, highlighting the guru's role in guiding disciples towards perfection.

Previous translation: I have fortunately been instructed by you and thus great favor has been bestowed upon me. I thank God and I have listened with open ears to your pure words. Purport: Srila Rupa Goswami has given directions in his Bhakti Rasamrita Sindhu on how to accept a bona fide spiritual master and how to deal with him. First, the desiring candidate must find a bona fide spiritual master and then he must very eagerly receive instructions from him and execute them. This is reciprocal service. A bona fide spiritual master, a saintly person always desires to elevate a common man who comes to him, because everyone is under the delusion of Maya and is forgetful of his prime duty, Krishna Consciousness. Saintly person always desires that everyone becomes a saintly person. It is the function of a saintly person to invoke Krishna Consciousness in every forgetful man. Manu said that he was advised and instructed by Kardama Muni he was very much favored. He considered himself lucky to receive the message, by oral reception. It is especially mentioned here that one should be very inquisitive to hear with open ears from the authorized source of a bona fide spiritual master. How is one to receive? One should receive the transcendental message by oral reception. The word Karna Randhrahey means through the holes of the ears. The favor of the spiritual master is not received through any other part of the body but the ears. This does not mean however that the spiritual master gives a particular type of mantra through the ears in exchange for some dollars and if the man meditates on that he achieves perfection and becomes God within six months. Such reception through the ears is bogus. The real fact is that a bona fide spiritual master knows the nature of a particular man and what sort of duties he can perform in Krishna Consciousness and he instructs him in that way. He instructs him through the ear not privately but publicly. You are fit for such and such a work in Krishna Consciousness you can act in this way. One person is advised to work in Krishna Consciousness by working in the deity's room another is advised to act in Krishna Consciousness by performing editorial work another is advised to do preaching work another is advised to carry out Krishna Consciousness in the cooking department. There are different departments of activities in Krishna Consciousness and the spiritual master knowing the particular ability of a particular man trains him in such a way that he becomes perfect. Bhagavad Gita makes it clear that one can attain the highest perfection in spiritual life simply by offering service according to his ability just as Arjuna served Krishna by his ability in the military art. Arjuna offered his service fully as a military man and he became perfect. Similarly an artist can attain perfection simply by performing artistic work on the direction of the spiritual master. If one is a literary man he can write articles and poetry for the service of God under the direction of the spiritual master. One has to receive the message of the spiritual master regarding how to act in one's capacity for the spiritual master is expert in giving

#### respect, super-soul, Vaishnava etiquette
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/N8YK8REL7t0?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Offering respect to his devotee is more valuable than offering respect to him."
**Summary:** This segment explains that offering respect to a Vaishnava is offering respect to Vishnu, as Vaishnavas are temples of Vishnu, and that respect is ultimately offered to the super-soul within.

It may be argued that since Daksha was the father-in-law of Lord Shiva, it was certainly the duty of Lord Shiva to offer him respect. In answer to that argument, it is explained here that when a learned person stands up or offers obeisances in welcome, he offers respect to the super-soul who is sitting within everyone's heart. It is seen, therefore, among Vaishnavas that even when a disciple offers obeisance to a spiritual master, the spiritual master immediately returns the obeisances because they are mutually offered not to the body but to the super-soul. Therefore, the spiritual master also offers respect to the super-soul situated in the body of the disciple. The Lord says in Srimad Bhagavatam that offering respect to his devotee is more valuable than offering respect to him. Devotees do not identify with the body. So, offering respect to a Vaishnava means offering respect to Vishnu. It is stated there also that as a matter of etiquette, as soon as one sees a Vaishnava, one must immediately offer him respect, indicating the super-soul sitting within. A Vaishnava sees the body of a temple of Vishnu. Since Lord Shiva already has offered respect to the super-soul in Krishna consciousness, offering respect to Daksha, who has identified with the body, was already performed, there is no need to offer respect to his body, for that is not directed by any Vedic injunction. Thus ends.

#### guru, parampara, spiritual master, mercy
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Dy9VGtyDXi8?t=41
**Verse References:** BG 4.34
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Unless one is fortunate enough to have the dust of the lotus feet of a mahatma on one's head, there is no possibility of perfection in spiritual life."
**Summary:** This segment emphasizes the importance of the parampara system and the grace of a spiritual master in achieving spiritual perfection, highlighting that rituals alone are insufficient without the blessings of a great soul.

Translation on purpose by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada. Translation: It is my good fortune that I have been able to see you, for you cannot easily be seen by persons who have not subdued the mind or controlled the senses. I am all the more fortunate to have touched my head to the blessed dust of your feet. Purport by Srila Prabhupada: The perfection of transcendental life can be achieved simply by touching the holy dust of the feet of a holy man. In the Bhagavatam it is said, mahat pada rajo 'bhishekam, which means to be blessed by the holy dust of the lotus feet of a mahat, or great devotee. As stated in Bhagavad Gita, mahatmanas tu, those who are great souls are under the spell of spiritual energy, and their symptom is that they fully engage in Krishna consciousness for the service of the Lord. Therefore, they are called mahatmas. Unless one is fortunate enough to have the dust of the lotus feet of a mahatma on one's head, there is no possibility of perfection in spiritual life. The parampara system of disciplic succession is very important as a means of spiritual success. One becomes a mahat by the grace of his mahat spiritual master. If one takes shelter of the lotus feet of a great soul, there is every possibility of one's also becoming a great soul. When Maharaj Rahugana asked Jadabharata about his wonderful achievements of spiritual success, he replied to the king that spiritual success is not possible simply by following the rituals of religion or simply by converting oneself into a sanyasi or offering sacrifices as recommended in the scriptures. These methods are undoubtedly helpful for spiritual realization, but the real effect is brought about by the grace of a mahatma. By the grace of a mahatma, in Vishvanatha Chakravarti Thakura's eight stanzas of prayers to the spiritual master, it is clearly stated that simply by satisfying the spiritual master, one can achieve the supreme success in life, and in spite of executing all ritualistic performances, if one cannot satisfy the spiritual master, one has no access to spiritual perfection. Here the word akritatmanam is very significant. Atma means body, soul, or mind, and akritatma means the common man who cannot control the senses or the mind. Because the common man is unable to control the senses and the mind, it is his duty to seek the shelter of a great soul or a great devotee of the Lord and just try to please him. That will make his life perfect. A common man cannot rise to the topmost stage of spiritual realization simply by following the rituals and religious principles. He has to take shelter of a bona fide spiritual master and work under his direction faithfully and sincerely, then he becomes perfect without a doubt.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/ZQJ8JEmcW0Q?t=0
**Verse References:** —

**Summary:** The speaker reads and explains a verse and purport emphasizing the roles of Brahmanas and Kshatriyas in protecting society and each other, highlighting the importance of Brahmanical culture.

OM NAMO BHAGAVATE VASUDEVAYA. Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 3, Chapter 22, Verse 3: TATRANAYA SHRI CHACCASMAN TATRANAYA SHRI CHACCASMAN DOHA SAHASRAT SAHASRAPAD DOHA SAHASRAT SAHASRAPAD RIDAYAM TASHYAHI BRAMMA RIDAYAM TASHYAHI BRAMMA SATRAM ANRAM PRACHAT SATE SATRAM ANRAM PRACHAT SATE. Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada: "For the protection of the Brahmanas, the thousand-leaded Supreme Being created us, the Satryas, from His thousand arms. Hence the Brahmanas are said to be His heart and the Satryas, His arms." Purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada: "Satryas are specifically meant to maintain the Brahmanas because if the Brahmanas are protected and the head of civilization is protected, Brahmanas are supposed to be protected. Brahmanas are supposed to be the head of the social body. If the head is clear and has not gone mad, then everything is in proper position. The Lord is described thus, Namo Brahmania Devaya, Go Brahmana Hitayacha. The purport of this prayer is that the Lord specifically protects the Brahmanas and the cows, and then He protects all other members of society. It is His will that universal welfare work depends on the protection of cows and Brahmanas. Thus Brahmanical culture and cow protection are the basic principles for human civilization. Satryas are especially meant to protect the Brahmanas, as is the supreme will of the Lord. Go Brahmana Hitayacha. As the Supreme Will of the Lord, Go Brahmana Hitayacha. As the Supreme Will of the Lord, Go Brahmana Hitayacha. Because within the body, the heart is a very important part, so the brahmanas are also the important element in human society. The satryas are more like the whole body. Even though the whole body is bigger than the heart, the heart is more important."

**Summary:** This segment focuses on the importance of associating with saintly persons and receiving their favor, as highlighted in the Srimad Bhagavatam and exemplified by Srila Prabhupada's experience with his guru.

Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya. Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 3, Chapter 22, Text No. 5: Tavasandarshanadeva Chinname Sarvasamchayaha Yatsvayam Bhagavanpretya Dharmamaharirakshisho. There was no preparation for this but somehow or other, he desired it and by his grace, we are now engaged in executing his order which has given us a transcendental occupation and has saved and liberated us from the occupation of material activities. Thus, it is actually a fact that if one meets a saintly person completely engaged in transcendental duties and achieves his favour, then one's life mission becomes complete. What is not possible to achieve in thousands of lives can be achieved in one moment if there is an opportunity to meet a saintly person. A saintly person has the power because of his spiritual advancement to give immediate liberation to the conditioned soul. Just then the steward in the aircraft, it was Venezuela Airlines, so a young woman walked by and she stood next to Paramahamsa and she was staring at what they are eating, some very strange yellow puffed rice for her it was, and very strangely she put her hand into the little plate of Shrutakirti, took a little, put it in her mouth and looked at them and said, "Very tasty," and he was shocked and suddenly some hand coming and he was just recovering and then she said, "What is this?" He didn't know, he said, "You know, we are vegetarians and we eat some of these." "Oh, you are vegetarians, very nice, do you want something more?" And so he asked Prabhupada, "You want something she is asking?" And so Prabhupada said, "Fruits." "Oh yes, I will get you some fruits," she said. And then again she asked, "Do you want anything to drink?" And then he asked Prabhupada, she said, "Prabhupada, she is asking, do you want to drink anything?" And said Prabhupada said, "Hot milk." Prabhupada liked hot milk also and so she said, "Yes, you can give hot milk," and she said, "Okay, if there is anything more also I will get for you," and she went away. So Shrutakirti turned to Prabhupada and said, "Prabhupada, look at this, what a miracle, how she got, how she got maha maha prasadam." I mean he was trying to say that Prabhupada said, "That's the good nature of a woman, always they want, they are always ready, eager to do service." Actually, he was telling about maha maha prasadam, but then Prabhupada was looking at her willingness to bring some fruits and milk and all of those wanting to do. So Prabhupada appreciated her and then she went away and they brought the fruits.

#### Lord Shiva, modes of material nature, detachment, service to the Lord
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/x2NZylQwKG8?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Even though He is in charge of the mode of ignorance in this material world, He is unaffected by any of the modes of material nature."
**Summary:** Lord Shiva is described as being in charge of the mode of ignorance but detached from material nature, engaged in service to the Supreme Lord, which is also the spirit of Vaishnavas.

The position of Lord Shiva is that He is in charge of all the living entities in the mode of ignorance. He takes care of them for their material desires. Those who are inflicted by the three modes of material nature, at every opportunity they are trying to get material pleasure for their body, for their mind, for their intellect, for their false ego. Even though He is in charge of the mode of ignorance in this material world, He is unaffected by any of the modes of material nature. He is exemplified by His detachment from this material world. He never accepts luxurious dress, garland, ornament, etc. He is engaged in His own Self. Only one who is engaged in His own Self can actually be free from the three modes of material nature. He understands His own Self as part and parcel, as part of the Supreme Lord Krishna. Knowing that, He is always engaged in the service of the Supreme Lord. This is the spirit of the Vaishnavas also.

### The Purpose of the Varnashrama System in Society | Sri Madhu Pandit Dasa | SB 4.14.18 | 16.07.2024
**Speaker:** HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

#### Varna and Ashrama, Duty, Devotional Service, Government's Role
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/dE_AegZmFKs?t=0
**Verse References:** BG 4.13, BG 9.27, BG 18.46
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The state's duty and the citizens' duty are very nicely explained in this verse."
**Summary:** HG Madhu Pandit Dasa reads and explains a verse and purport from Srimad Bhagavatam, emphasizing the importance of Varna and Ashrama for societal harmony and the government's role in ensuring citizens engage in devotional service.

Om Om Bhagavate Vasudevaya. Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 4, Chapter 14, Text 18. Canto 4, Chapter 14, Text 18. Translation: In Perpetual Vaisalaprabhupada Jaya, "The king is supposed to be pious in whose state and cities the general population strictly observes the system of eight social orders of Varna and Ashrama and where all citizens engage in worshipping the Supreme Personality of Godhead by their particular occupation." Purport: "The state's duty and the citizens' duty are very nicely explained in this verse. The activities of the government head or king as well as the activities of the citizens must be so directed that ultimately everyone engages in devotional service to the Supreme Personality of Godhead. The king or the government head is supposed to be representative of the Supreme Personality of Godhead and is therefore supposed to see that things go on nicely and the citizens situated in the scientific social order comprise four Ashramas, four Varnas and four Ashramas. In the Vishnu Purana, it is stated that unless people are educated or situated in the scientific social order comprised of four Varnas, Brahmana, Kshatriya, Vaishya and Shudra, then four Ashramas, Brahmacharya, Grahastha, Vanaprastha and Sannyasa, society can never be considered real human society nor can it make any advancement towards the ultimate goal of human life. It is the duty of the government to see that things go on in terms of Varna and Ashrama. As stated here in Bhagavan Etnapurusha, the Supreme Personality of Godhead Krishna is the Etnapurusha. As stated in Bhagavad Gita, Bhaktaram, Yajna Tapasam, Krishna is the ultimate purpose of all sacrifice. He is also the enjoyer of all sacrifices. Therefore, he is known as Etnapurusha. The word Etnapurusha indicates Lord Vishnu or Lord Krishna or any personality of Godhead in the category of Vishnu Tattva. In perfect human society, people are situated in the orders of Godhead. They follow the orders of Varna and Ashrama and are engaged in worshipping Lord Vishnu by their respective activities. Every citizen engaged in an occupation renders service by the resultant actions of his activities. That is the perfection of life. As stated in Bhagavad Gita, yatah pravrttir bhuthanam ena sarvam idam tatam swakarmanatam abhyarchya siddhim vindati manavah: By worship of the Lord, who is the source of all beings and who is all-pervading, man can, in the performance of his own duty, attain perfection. Thus, the Brahmana Kshatriya Vaishya Shudras must execute their prescribed duties as these duties are stated in the Shastras. In this way, everyone can satisfy the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Vishnu. The king or the government head has to see that the citizens are thus engaged. In other words, the state or the government must not deviate from its duty by declaring that state is a secular state, which has no interest in whether or not the people advance in Varna Ashrama. Today, people engage in government service and people who rule over the citizens have no respect for Varna Ashrama Dharma. They complacently feel that the state is secular. In such a government, no one can be happy. People must follow the Varna Ashrama Dharma and the king must see that they follow it nicely." Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta purport.

The modern mind is so diseased, when we hear something, we immediately try to find a proof for it from the scientific field or some other field. One mathematician proved that mathematics is not complete and consistent. So, mathematicians themselves proved that mathematics is incomplete. So, by holding on to the incomplete field, how can you learn conclusive truths? #### illusion, perception of God, conditioned soul
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/lLyEqGSVdx4?t=121
**Verse References:** BG 7.25
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "This is why we cannot understand who God is or see Him face to face."
**Summary:** The speaker explains why conditioned souls cannot see God, even when He appears before them, because they falsely believe themselves to be independent controllers.

Thus, we also expect the Lord to protect us from this dangerous condition. Text 25: Ya Eka Eesho Nijamaya Ya Naham Sasarjaya Nanu Shujama Vishvam Vayamnaya Syaapipurah Sameeha Taha Pashyamalingam Prudhagisham Anina Pashyamalingam Prudhagisham Anina Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swamishya Prabhupada Translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead who created us by His external potency, and by whose mercy we expand the creation of the universe, is always situated before us as the Supersoul, but we cannot see His form. We are unable to see Him because all of us think that we are separate and independent gods. Purport by Shri Prabhupada: Here is an explanation of why the conditioned soul cannot see the Supreme Personality of Godhead, face to face. Even though the Lord appears before us as Lord Krishna or Lord Ramachandra and lives in human society as a leader or king, the conditioned soul cannot understand Him. Abhajananti Mamudha Manushim Tanumashritam Rascals, mudhas, deride the Supreme Personality of Godhead, thinking Him an ordinary human being. However, insignificantly, the Lord appears before us as Lord Krishna, and we think that we are also God, that we can create a universe, that we can create, or that we can create another God. This is why we cannot see or understand the Supreme Personality of Godhead. In this regard, Shri Madhvacharya says, Lingam eva pashyamaha kadachit abhimanastu. Devanam apisanyava prayaha kaleshu nastya va taratam yena sopitu We are all conditioned to various degrees, but we think we are God. This is why we cannot understand who God is or see Him face to face.

So, when the scientists are analyzing, they understood that whenever an ant gets a grain, it divides that into two and keeps them into their godown. Ants have godowns, storekeepers, everything is there. So then they were very curious, why is the ant breaking the grain into two? Then they figured out that if the grain is broken, then it will not, you know, germinate. It will not become a seedling, a small plant. So, that's why the ants break the seeds, so that it won't grow into some plant or something and they miss the food. So that's going on. And meanwhile, they saw there is one coriander seed. And this time, the ant has broken the coriander seed into four parts. And they were surprised. Why is this? Other seeds are only two. Now it is broken into four. So they started analyzing. They found that coriander seed, if you break them into two, still seedling is possible. It can germinate and become small seedlings. So that's why the ant knows that this is a coriander seed. ### The Duties & Qualities of a Brahmana | Sri Vigraha Dasa | SB 1.18.34 | 11.08.2024
**Speaker:** HG Satya Gaura Chandra Dasa

#### Shringi's curse, Brahmana's role, False prestige
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/4pPYmm9wJI0?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "He compared the king to a watchdog and so it was wrong for the king to enter the home of a brahmana and ask for water from the same pot."
**Summary:** The speaker reads and explains a verse from Srimad Bhagavatam about Shringi cursing King Parikshit, highlighting Shringi's inappropriate comparison of the king to a dog and the false prestige associated with being a Brahmana.

Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 1, Creation, Chapter 18, Entitled Parikshit Cursed by a Brahmana Boy, Text 34 Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada Translation Shringi continued to say The descendants of the kingly orders are definitely designated as watchdogs and they must keep themselves at the door. On what grounds can dogs enter the house and claim to dine with the master on the same plate? Purport by Srila Prabhupada Parikshit Cursed by a Brahmana Boy, Text 34 Translation and purport by His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada Certainly knew that the king asked for water from his father and the father did not respond. He tried to explain away his father's inhospitality in an impertinent manner, befitting an uncultured boy. He was not at all sorry for the king's not being well received. On the contrary, he justified the wrong act in a way characteristically, of the brahmanas of Kali Yuga. He compared the king to a watchdog and so it was wrong for the king to enter the home of a brahmana and ask for water from the same pot. The dog is certainly reared by its master but that does not mean that the dog shall claim to dine and drink from the same pot. This mentality of false prestige, is the cause of downfall of the perfect social order. And we can see that, in the beginning it was started by the inexperienced son of a brahmana. As the dog is never allowed to enter within the room and hearth, although it is reared by the master, similarly, according to Shringi, the king had no right to enter the house of Shamika Rishi. The king was not allowed to enter the house of Shamika Rishi. According to the boy's opinion, the king was on the wrong side and not his father and thus, he justified his silent father.

Now is this some caste system? That is talked about, in modern terms. No, this is merely, division of labor, in the society. To keep, Krishna in the center, based on one's, qualities, one's, interest of work, one can be whatever he is. But, we keep Krishna in the center, and work. That is called the, Daivi Varanashrama system. Since this system is created by, none other than, the Supreme Lord himself. This is a universal thing. It's not that only in India it exists. It's a universal thing. Srila Prabhupada points out this. When he went to the America, he asked, don't you see in your society, you have intellectual people, you have administrative class of people, you have business class of people, you also have labor class of people. Everywhere you go, four classes of people exist. So this is Varanashrama system. Intellectual people are Brahmanas, who are supposed to, share knowledge to the society. They are like the brain of the body. In the body, they are the brain. Right? Brain is very important, to give us directions. What to do, what not to do. It gives us, directions, well thought decisions. Right? That is Brahmanas. And then, Kshatriyas are those, who are into administration. Who are into, taking care of the, citizens. Protecting them. Kshatrayate iti kshatriya. This is the definition of Kshatriya. One who, protects others from getting hurt. He is called a Kshatriya. Not like modern day, administrative class leaders, who sit in a nice bulletproof, you know, nice room, and they allow the poor soldiers, to go and die on the battlefields. That is not a Kshatriya. Kshatriya must, help others, from getting hurt, by himself exposing, his body. Using weapons. That is Kshatriya. And then, Vaishyas, are the business class of people. Krishi, Vaanijyam, Vaishya Karma Swabhavajam. Krishna says in the Bhagavad Gita. So, what are the business, what are the, what are the activities, designated for the Vaishyas? Krishi, agriculture. Goraksha, cow protection. Vaanijyam, trade and commerce. These are the things, which are designated as duties, for the Vaishyas. The business class of people. And then, Paricharyatmakam Karyam, Shudra Karma Swabhavajam. So, for the, Shudras, the labor class of people, Paricharyatmakam, serving, service, physical labor, is actually the designated work.

He went and kidnapped a married woman because he was lusty. So but he was highly educated. The moment he was asked to choose between Ayodhya and going to forest, he happily chose to go to forest and gave up Ayodhya to his own brother Bharat. In fact, in Ramayana we see when Bharat was ready to offer Ayodhya back to Ram, Ram was very happy being in the forest. He wanted Bharat to continue to be the king and take care of Ayodhya till he returns. So Ram was very satisfied with what was there in his life. He was not an ambitious, over ambitious person like Ravan, who was ready to snatch property from his own brother. Here Ram is happily handing over Ayodhya to his own brother Bharat. And Ram, even though Shurpanaka came and offered herself, Ram did not become lusty. He had control over himself. He used his wisdom, he used his power, his knowledge to have control over himself, to follow the promise given to his own wife that ekapatni vratasta. When a woman, a beautiful woman coming and offering herself with her own consent, let's have fun, Ram said no, I cannot, I would like to follow my promise and I'm not interested in this. But Ravan became lusty. Ram exhibited self-control. So we need wise people, not just knowledge of the world, but knowledge of the world and knowledge of the people, not educated people.
